reviewText:
When I bought Hydrophobia, I was expecting dynamic gameplay revolving around an awesome ability allowing the manipulation of water. Upon playing the game, I realized this is not much more than a repetitive tech demo for water physics. The gameplay is alright, but I found it to be quite boring. When I finally attained the ability to manipulate water, I found it to be lacking in functionality, and discovered that it is only useable on the final boss and in a few rooms before it.

I also realized, that in order to attain 100% completion of the game, you need to be able to accomplish a difficult and unclear task on the first attempt. After failing the task once, it can not be attempted again. The only way to get 100% at that point, is to manually delete the save and to restart from the very beginning. This can be tedious to do as the task is found at the end of Act 1 or the beginning of Act 2, so you have to play for quite a while to get back, and you also have to reattain every medal that you might have had at that point, which in my case was all but two or three.

The game includes a feedback option that allows you to choose aspects of the game that you did or did not like. Upon researching the company that made the game, I found out that they went bankrupt and that the feedback is now meaningless.

Overall I'd say that this game is extremely disappointingly repetitive and lacking in gameplay, but I suppose that it is worth its low price.

reviewText: This game was originally released in an unfinished state, and consequently received a very bad reputation as result.  However, the developer has gone back and addressed most of the complaints and the result is a fun, technically impressive game that is well worth the money when on-sale. The controls, gameplay, and graphics are all above-average for a budget game and you will see things being done with water physics that you won't see in other games of this type.  If you enjoy third person shooters and/or neat water in games then you really can't go wrong.

reviewText:
As majority of people say, not even worth the 0.49€ as many (including me) bought it for. Yes, the water physics and look is gorgeous, but that is it. The rest is absolutely awfull. They should never have made it like this, why not just make a physics engine video and spare the money on making this atrocity.
1. Cutscenes -> huge ton of them, first you have a cutscene, then walk 2 meters (no joke, 2 meters, or even less), another cutscene, another 2 meters, another cutscene, another 3 meters, yet another cutscene. This game is filled with useless cutscenes that could have been done differently. There are cutscenes hidden as a dialogue, as camera feeds, as danger, they are everywhere to the point where I spent 15 times grabbing and letting go of my mouse every minute.
2. Voice acting is just bad, main protagonist is so irritating I wanted to kill her myself, and the male support role jokes in so many stupid ways that I would smack him through the radio. There is difference between being a smartass and being a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ when you make a completely stupid joke as you're about to die.
3. Bugs, oh so many, game is brutally linear and nothing wrong with that, but even being linear and with everything shining at you at where you're supposed to go, I got myself stuck several times to the point I couldn't find a way further. Small room, nowhere to go, nothing to shoot/press/do.

1 hour wasted, 0.49€ wasted. Should have bought myself a beer instead, pour it into a glass, marvel at the water physics and then drink it. would be much better experience.

reviewText:
Hydrophobia is a 3rd person action / shooter based around some great water dynamics. The water will flow from one room to the next, raise, lower, put out fires, and electricity will damage anything near it. Its a lot like being in a Zelda water dungeon.

This is a good game with gameplay mechanics that are on par with big budget games like Uncharted and Batman: Arkham Asylum. It has the ledge climbing, destructible environments, swimming, camera hacking, wall cover, sneaking and even a Navi, which is similar to Arkham Asylum's detective mode, which will let you find encryption codes on walls, open doors from a far, hack consoles with a mini game, access cameras.

There's a great balance between problem solving, shooting and exploration. There are only a few guns and really you won't need any other gun but the default phaser that you can hold the trigger to charge for bigger damage. There is a cover system, but I rarely used it. The downside for some purists would be the aim seems off since there's a 'target lock' system. What I mean is aim near something you can shoot and it lights red and will still count as a hit. Its not the best, but it stays in the realm of good. Even though the game encourages you to drown foes, electrocute them, blow up barrels and so on, it didn't really seem like I killed anyone in cool ways other than exploding barrels.

The controls feel good, aim, shoot, move, move camera, roll (although I never used it once), jump, sneak, weapon wheel, diving, emerging, sticking to cover and so on. The heroine's movement is just a little stiff, but that's one of the only downsides to this game.

The story is good for an indie action game, terrorists have taken over your cruise ship and you need to stop them. You've got a helpful voice that chimes in and tells you what to do, but it never feels like too much instruction. There are things left for yourself to figure out. There's even a nice waypoint to guide you in the general direction if you chose to use it to make the game easier for you to stay on task. It will always show you a dot on the screen where you need to go, but getting to that point is on you.

The game looks great, with really nice water effects and camera sprays. The voice acting sounds good and there are an over abundance of cut scenes at the start, but they ease up in frequency as the game goes on.

I've got the game on PSN and PC. Graphics wise I'd say PC is better, but it seems to be a beast on my PC's processor and not the graphics card. It is a game best played with a controller. The downside with PC is the camera feels chaotic.

The game is short and sweet. The whole single player campaign is like 3 - 4 hours (I completed it for PSN) and at less than $5 I'm fine with that. There are challenge rooms to extend the game's length. It doesn't overstay its welcome and its a game that makes me want to play other things that the developers come up with, but alas they're defunct as of 2012.

reviewText:
Short version: 68%Hydrophobia has a memorable level design and visual themes, along with rather impressive water flow simulation, and an average, but decent TPS system. Still, all of these feel a little unpolished, awkward when playing, resulting in a mediocre game at best.

Long version:Dark Energy Digital spent years with developing a game engine with fluid simulation, and Hydrophobia was supposed to showcase its capabilities. Sadly, the game tanked so hard that it drowned the company, but not before they salvaged some of it by releasing the Prophecy update that more or less ties up the loose ends of what was originally meant to be an entire trilogy.

Not that there is too much story: set in the somewhat near future– where overpopulation has caused the rich to flee to a floating city, away from society’s increasing problems– we play as Kate, a system engineer who ends up in the middle of a terrorist attack. She spends about 3-4 hours trying to survive while getting off the most damaged parts of the ship, aided by the mandatory tech guy guiding her from afar.

The game mechanics are basic third-person action adventure: climb, jump, shoot the two available enemy types (normal and heavy trooper), and try to use the water to your advantage when it is not trying to kill you. It’s not really boring, but the level design does get repetitive.
The showcased water mechanics work well; at least up until you get the power to control it. (Despite what the store suggests, that happens only about 10 minutes before the end of the game.) This was intended to be used only in the upcoming games, and they didn’t really have much time to put into it, so it’s rather awkward to control and just looks ugly, in stark contrast to all other water mechanics.

Could Hydrophobia be a better game? Probably, but we will never find that out. As it is now, it is still enjoyable, to a degree, but it will feel lacking in all areas, if you decide to try it.

reviewText:
Straight up, I don't recommend this as a game. This is one of the most average third person shooters I have ever played. It's not necessarily a bad game, but it's not worth playing if you aren't going to buy it for the water effects/physics. If you are okay with a tech demo, then consider getting it.

Hydrophobia: Prophecy was developed by an indie company, so straight away you know that it won't easily compete with the best TPS games out there.

If I had to compare the entire game to other games, I would say that they took the climbing mechanics from Tomb Raider/Uncharted and made the sinking ship level from Tomb Raider: Underworld" into a game.

The game was made for almost no other reason than to show off the engine. It has dynamic water with physics that are incredible. You can shoot out windows to flood rooms even more and the water can either help you in combat or it will just make things more difficult. Unfortunately the game is short and doesn't really speed up. The game is apparently the first in a series

reviewText:
This is a tricky game to review, and it really makes me wish that Steam had a neutral option.

Although the description boasts about allowing you to control water, you don't actually gain this ability until the tail end of the game. This is rather unfortunate, as this power is what makes the game worth playing in the first place. Without this ability this is a mediocre game at best. It is buggy, generic, and sometimes a bit of an annoyance. However, I still enjoyed my time playing this game mainly due to how impressed I was by the water physics. It seems as though the entire budget for this game went in to this aspect, and it really does pay off. The water is lots of fun to play with, and is fantastically animated.

I would recommend ONLY buying this if you are willing to play through the lackluster first half of the game just to reach what is essentially a water physics demo. I bought this game on sale for $0.50, and was happy with the experience I got for this price.

reviewText:
Difficulty: Easy
The Bottom Line: Ambitious/Good
Score 7.0

Note: This Game Been Tried Out And Reviewed In Offline Mode or On Another Steam Account And Or Consoles.

Hydrophobia Prophecy is a Good game. If you can accept before playing that the game takes place in a breached ship and there will be a lot of water and disorienting waves, the action will be fun and you'll find yourself holding your breath in tight spots

The climbing and acrobatics is easy to learn and yet still can be intense when you need to balance above a fiery pit. Sometimes what you need to climb on is not very obvious, and finding where to go can be harder than actually getting there

Combat is where the game does not shine, but it is not difficult to master and for a casual gamer, is simple enough that they can have a good time with it.

Normal mode will have you breezing through the game in relative easiness, so if you are looking for a challenge you'll need to pick hard mode.

Overall: This game is well worth it. If you haven't  played the first Hydrophobia, play this

reviewText:
Hmmm. Where do I start? Personally, I purchased this game due to curiosity, and because it seemed really-really interesting, and of course, it was on sale. I was a bit disappointed at first, but intrigued by the game engine used. The game has incredible water physics.

I recommend this game for the same reason why I purchased it. if you're curious, seems interesting & it is on sale.

Things to consider if you're planning on purchasing:
Graphics:
The graphics setting is not in-game but pre-game. Which means you have no option on changing the graphics setting when you are in game.
Graphics at medium setting dropped my FPS. Compared to other games published in 2011 that I've played, this is not supposed to happen.
Somehow the game crashed, probably due to the processing of the graphics.
Controls:
You will always be sprinting, even at the beginning of the game where you're in your residence. Its annoying, really. You can always crouch to walk to avoid sprinting.
When you use the flash light, there is light but your character is not holding any flash light. I'm assumming the light comes from her headband.
I'm using a Logitech F310 gamepad with this game and overall, I think the controls are okay.
Map:
The map interface design is very weird. Interesting, but weird.
The map control using the F310 gamepad is weird. Moving the map using the gamepad is very troublesome.
I have not tried it with a mouse though
Character Background Development:
You will know that the main character, Kate has a water-related phobia. (as the name of the game suggests)
You will wonder what the word Prophecy in the game title actually means.  No story was developed around the word Prophecy.
When you dive, having less than 50% of oxygen left, you will hear things. (this annoys me a lot)
Through the end of the game, you will not know what happened to Scoot, Kate's partner who guided her throughout the game.
You will wonder what S.A.R.A. is and when were you introduced or atleast warned about it.
You will end up with a major cliffhanger playing this game.
This is a game I'd recommend to new game developers, to learn what not to do in designing the game, learn from the mistakes made making this game.

reviewText:

Swimming is pretty rough, and this is compounded by the fact that the game celebrates its water physics. The cover based shooting isn't bad, cover to cover works, I don't get what sprint does, except that she leaps forward about 5 feet then resumes regular walking speed. reviewText:
Full Review[yarow12.tumblr.com]

Hydrophobia: Prophecy's main problem lies in the (only) boss fight and ending. The endboss is hell to deal with, but not too difficult once you figure it out (don't run out of barrels or you're screwed). The ending itself is... episodic. It wouldn't be a problem if a sequel was in the works, but this is highly unlikely so our best chances of satisfaction lie in getting a spiritual successor to a pretty great 10-hour game that has many surprising qualities that make it oh so worth playing. It even managed to take me back to my earlier days of gaming.

There may only be one general path to follow at all times with some side/backtracking included, but I never noticed because of how expansive the ship that 98% of the game takes place on felt. The in-game map is very useful, by the way.

There are tons (72?) of collectibles (objects, documents, Malthus documents) and medals.
Wait, stop running! What's that on the shelf? Go grab it. Awesome, document 24 out of 48 found.

There are multiple ways to take on enemies.
Can you not, to save your own life, shoot a moving target? Aim for an explosive barrel (boom), electrical conduit (electrical boom), gas tank (flaming boom), or electrical wire (zzzap) that's conveniently hanging above a large puddle of water.
Tired of taking cover during shootouts? Flood the room by shooting holes in breakable walls and windows. Have fun aiming up, down, and all around as enemies shoot you from every direction while completely underwater.

The game's story and lore lies in the hidden messages left on the walls (think Bioshock) by the Malthusians--eco-friendly terrorists who love the environment more than your life (prepare to be disturbed). These messages can only be viewed using the MAVI scanner--a badass tablet that can hack cameras and consoles (fun, but tricky to get 100% perfection); download ciphers to unlock encrypted doors; reveal how much water will fill the room once a door is opened; and open the door 'cause ♥♥♥♥ that fire.

The in-game database is basically your bestiary or encyclopedia of Hydrophobia.
Found a bottle of sleeping pills in your apartment? Read about it and learn more about this attractive female you're playing as. Or say ♥♥♥♥ it" and continue your shooting spree.
Scanned another hidden message left by the Malthusians? Read one of many interesting excerpts from "From the works of Thomas Malthus".

Hate universal ammo (think Deus Ex: Invisible War)? How about a reversal? Universal gun
date: baby! One gun; five ammo types (rapid-fire

In sum, it's a very-very-very mediocre 3-view shooter with female heroine on the big ship which was stormed by terrorists. It has a quite simplistic gameplay, where nothing is original, but, on the top of all - it is so short, that it looks like demo-version, and not a complete game.

I've already finished that game once (not on Steam), and I'll do it second time, but only because I've been a bad boy, and need to be punished.

What exactly do I have against that game, you may ask me? Well, the same thing we all have against cheaters and other freaks in the multiplayer: they destroy our hopes to have a good time.
Now goes the major spoiler: this game ending, when normal player is only warming up to some contest. Remember that we were promised by blurb? Control above the water! Just look at the title screen: there you are, a water-driving superwoman!
In the game, there are only three acts, and the first two of them can be counted as a prologue. You start normally, step by step you're getting the game's mechanics, climbing and diving through the first trials, saving some powerful ammo for the rest of the game. Then goes the first serious shootout, where you probably might use some of the powerful shots you've collected. Then you learning to control water... two more rooms, and then BLAM! - the boss fight! And that's all!

The Hydrophobia could have been a very good game... but it seems that over 95% of resources were spended strictly on the engine. We don't have enough game there, just a little prolonged presentation of that precious engine.
It usually can be finished in less than 5 hours... But there is a Major Bug with savegames (there are single checkpoint system). Every now and then when you're restarting Hydrophobia, it drops your savefiles to the pit of Oblivion. Sometimes they returning... after 4-5 reloading. Mostly - don't. There are other bugs, as well, but loosing the savegame looks like the game feature, which is more fluent than water itself!

I hate that game for what she could be - a very nice looking, smart-enough sleep-taker. But in our reality she's just a soother. 5.5/10 mark. You'll be much better with the Bioshock and Tomb Raider titles. And if you're really want some challenge,,, find Heavy Metal FAKK 2 - that's a real deal!

Hydrophobia Prophecy is an entertaining third person shooter that takes place in a sinking City-Ship. The action revolves around maneuvering through short mazes of flooded hallways, solving a few puzzles using the water mechanics, and getting into firefights, both above and under water. As you may have noticed, water plays a HUGE role in this game, and it should. Hydrophobia has some of the best water physics I have ever seen. It is almost worth playing just to mess around with the water physics.

reviewText:
Hydrophobia is an enjoyable little game that can easily be finished in two to three hours. It's a platformer with mild shooting elements set on a floating city beseiged by Malthusian-inspired terrorists.

The game is surprisingly feature rich for a small title like this, and the water effects are particularly impressive. You can open doors to flood rooms or drain them, you can use water to knock down and stun enemies, and you can also use water to overcome environmental hazards like fires or stray electrical wires. There's also a novel hacking minigame.

Considering the length, I'd appraise the game at $5.00 to $7.50 at most, and anything equal to or beneath that price point is a steal.

There's a plot, but it's told mainly through picked up documents. There's also a few fun little easter eggs for gamers.

If you like aquatic games, platforming, and blowing people away with a sonic pistol, then I recommend you check this one out.

reviewText:
There's a lot of little elements that make this game great however it has its rough edges.

*The graphics are really good imho although the world feels a bit too bland at times but that's probably a design choice (you're on board of an ultra modern ship)
*The music could be better, it's not really that memorable.
*The controls feel a bit clunky at times (playing on PC with keyboard and mouse)
it's easy enough to play though, but sometimes when alternating between diving & swimming at the surface & walking in deep water for example, it's kinda hard to predict your character precise movements.
*The water physics are great though I feel like there is room for even more improvement (I'm not sure how realistic they are though, I'm not a liquid physician)
*The story is engaging and felt original enough to me, however sometimes some elements of the gameplay could have been given a little more of a dramatic feeling. I won't say more so as not to spoil anything.
*The level design is overall alright, with a good mix of action & tomb raider like jumping & stuff. However it's a total corridor game, nothing is open ended here ever.Therefore if you get this game you can turn off the waypoints" option.

And finally a personnal gripe : yet another game with regenerative health
date: I abused it though because the enemies do hurt a lot when you get surprised.\n\nI have not finished the game yet
recommended: but I would honestly like Hydrophobia 2 to come our way and in my opinion it's worth more than the 1€ I paid for it on sale."

reviewText:
Short and unsatisfying.
For most of the storyline (a very apt estimate), water will mainly serve as a puzzle you can't directly influence.

Room upon room, water is either a hazard through loose electric wires (shoot the wires - puzzle solved), a requirement to get past fire (lots of that) but rarely makes you feel like suffocating.

And what about that water controlling stuff? You get it halfway Act 3 (the last act) with one trick, the water tower. Which serves for rarely anything more then heavy, uninspired lifting.

The boss is even worse, it's uninspired and unsatisfying to beat it.
The ending is basically a plothole. Villain defeated but the boat is still messed up with you in the thick of it, having just taken the antidote to remove your awesome powers (WHY???) .

Forget magically controlling liquids, you rarely get enough time with it to appreciate it to its fullest.
Hydrophobia is a water game. Sounds boring? It is boring.

reviewText:
Even though the entire game follows the same formulas like an older third-person shooter, for what the developers were striving to achieve, the game is fairly good.
Keep in mind that the developers' goal for this game was to build an excellent water physics engine, which was cutting-edge for 2011. That said, excellent visuals and comfortable controls are its best points, and its background story is better than most games.


tldr: Overall I would take this game as an interactive story with puzzle elements than an action-oriented game, and for $0.49 it is worth it.

reviewText: After getting some much-needed post-release work, Hydrophobia: Prophecy turned into a pretty decent third-person action game. It combines light platforming, combat and puzzle elements, none particularly amazing but which work when taken as a whole. The visuals and water physics are mind-blowing at times, and the story has some philosophically interesting (if not terribly original or in-depth) overtones. I believe it was ported from XBL, so a controller might come in handy.\n\nThe main drawbacks are 1) the very short length, and 2) the fact that some of the coolest stuff in the game is held out until the very end, such that you hardly get to use it. Combat isn't bad, but it's simplistic, revolving around different types of ammo fired from the same weapon. The developer having gone under means this one is probably a relic now. Still, it's a good budget title and well worth the few hours of gameplay it offers.

reviewText:
Hydrophobia:  Prophecy (Dark Energy Digital, 2011)

I've completed Hydrophobia: Prophecy and had a great time doing so.

It's true that this was originally meant to be the first game in a trilogy, that it had major problems upon release, that the rest of the trilogy was scrapped and a new version of this game created that incorporated (some) content from what were meant to be the follow-ups, and that it has since appeared dirt cheap in numerous bundled deals and on Steam.  But don't let any of that distract you from what is now, today, a polished product that is genuinely fun to play.

In short, Hydrophobia:  Prophecy is an action-adventure game with strong platforming elements, set on a huge ocean liner, or rather in the bowels of a huge ocean liner.  The gameplay is fairly standard.  You are able to shoot, with a variety of different projectiles at your disposal, but it's not a shooter by any stretch.

The level design is great, the controls work, defeating enemies and overcoming environmental challenges feel satisfying, and as mentioned above, the price is likely to be right regardless of where you choose to buy it.

SCORES

Graphics - 82 %

Water effects are brilliant;  the main character has terrible hair though (plastic dreadlocks on what is otherwise a gorgeous model), which I found somewhat distracting throughout.

Sound - 70 %

It works;  nothing particularly noteworthy though.

Execution - 75 %

The game, in this iteration, is a good execution of its core concept.

The storytelling via cinematics and viewscreens placed around the ship is effective.  You dislike the bad guys;  though sadly their politics are never as deeply explored as it could have been (likely owing to the trilogy being scrapped).

The free running-style gameplay and acrobatics work and never pose any problems, such as unexpected falls or missing jumps because of problematic surface detection.

One does feel that the setting (a huge ocean liner) could have been more interestingly presented, and it doesn't feel all that much like you're inside a huge ship on the ocean (regardless of copious amounts of water).  Again, it is likely that this concept was originally meant to be explored further.

The water manipulation powers from later in the game also feel a bit tacked on, as they obviously were, considering they weren't meant to be in the first episode at all.

Addictiveness - 80 %

I wanted to continue playing, and I did, and I pursued some achievements, and I enjoyed myself.  That sentence has about two ands" too many
recommended: the game is a bit like that.  You never know if you're close to the end and you don't really care.  It's fun getting there
hoursPlayed:
and that's mainly what matters (in my opinion).

Overall - 75 %

It's cheap.  It's good.  Buy it if you're into third-person exploration games with some shooting and a lot of acrobatics.

The achievements all appear to work
voteText: which I know is important to some people.  There are collectables
helpfulPercent: again
votesHelpful: if that is your sort of thing.  I just wanted a thrilling experience with an unsual setting
votesTotal: and I got what I wanted.\n\nI'm looking forward to doing another playthrough at some point.  And that's really the best recommendation there is."

reviewText:
TL;DR:I believe this is a very solid game and absolutley think I got my moneys worth out of it.
And I'd really like to see a sequel.

Pros:So the water, it's effects and how movements are in it look and feel stunningly real!
Runs really smooth even on my several year old laptop even though you have all theese water effects.
Overall graphics are great.
Sound and music is OK.
Story is OK.
Level Design is nice, even though pretty linear.
Puzzles are OK, pretty straight forward and not hard thinkabouters.
You can make choices (sometimes have to be quick about them) wheter to save someone or leave them to their fate.
Really like the MAVI (Mobile Automated Visual Interface) and what you can do with it!
You are like a smart commando triathlon acrobat; Climbing, swimming, balancing, rolling, swinging, jumping, shooting, hacking and everything else you're friggin' amazing at!
Really awesome nanotech water ability!
Cons:Controls are... OK, but they feel a little clunky.
Animations sometimes (not at all always) felt a bit stiff, most apparent during cutscenes.
Journal entries (who seems to be quite alot about what the protagonist feels and wants) and speech isn't always reflecting each other that well.
Map in the MAVI was not that easy to follow (not that you had to look at it since there wasn't many places to go except forward).
Sometimes while climbing, you get a fixed camera angle.
You can't always look in the direction you want, seems like the water and other objects can block the camera so you can't look up for example (unless ou use the MAVI)).
Sometimes the camera angle makes it so you can't see enemies while they can still shoot at you.
If you stand to close to the edge of ventilation shafts, you will start to drift/float out of the vent shaft and fall down.
So many collectibles it get's a bit tideous. Especially when some of them doesn't add anything ( IEY! I found a jar of pills that I can... uh, ok, just look at?).
The choises you make doesn't seem to have any impact on the story... but it gives you a 'Medal' (yet another collectible)!
Replay value; I'd say not that great unless you're an achievement junkie.
Not to spoil it too much, but I found it a bit sad that I didn't get to play around with the water abilities more.
Connclusion:First off I have to say that I was impressed with the water.
How it moved and what you could do with it.

Also I really liked the MAVI for some reason. It however was a tiny hard navigated/find the correct button for at first (my fault for not looking up the controls in the options menu) and the map in it wasn't maybe that easy to follow.
But it was some fun elements used with it. Hacking security cameras, finding hidden messages etc.

I would have wanted to have a longer campaign...
...and also I might have quite a list of cons...
Still however;
I believe this is a very solid game and absolutley think I got my moneys worth out of it.
Maybe because I played on Hard without the permanent objective marker. Plus I also at first tried to run around everywhere getting all objects and documents so it might have taken me a little longer that some.

And I'd really like to see a sequel.
Maybe with a little more polish to some of the cons above and I'd probably say it would be worth quite a bit more that what they charge for this baby.
...but sadly seems like the studio has been shut down, but I still hope that someday this title will re-emerge to the surface for us all to enjoy.

reviewText:
HYDROPHOBIA: PROPHECY
3rd person action/survival-adventure game

Rating 2/10

Interesting premise with nice water effects let down by clunky gameplay, bland locations and terrible voice acting.

It should be quite good, the idea of fighting terrorists who have hijacked a floating city whilst trying to overcome hull breaches and numerous fires. Sadly even though the water looks fantastic and creates a few genuine moments of panic as rooms fill with water the rest of the gameplay falls short.

The worst of these is the gun play. It's a real chore and it feels like you're fighting the controls more than the terrorists. Thankfully they aren't that often but they undermine the rest of the game. The voice acting and writing isn't much better, lifeless and wooden which doesn't help the repetitive and boring gameplay of collecting keys to open a series of identical doors.

They have great water tech, they just don't have a great game to go with it.

reviewText:
Primary conclusion: Best bought for game research/curiosity and little else. It's only an average third-person shooter, with an unfortunately short-lived exploration of a unique mechanic (water manipulation, towards the end of the game). Sell a few Steam cards, nab it during a sale, jump in with low expectations and enjoy a few hours of fairly impressive water simulation whilst shooting suicidal baddies (no really, that's their whole gig, convincing people to kill themselves, you'll see it all throughout the game, not advised if suicidal).

The good attempts:
Dynamic environmental element. Remember the old firefighting games? Replace fire with water then briefly give you control over it, that's Hydrophobia.
Charming dialogue. While it doesn't do it very well, at least it tried something a little more lighthearted and fun compared to some other games.
Emphasis on environmental awareness. Not in the save the world propaganda, but in keeping an eye out for electrical wires and the standard explosive tanks sitting about. It was nice that these options were available and encouraged through the unusual point system.
Scan/MAVI view. This was a neat little trick to hide stuff in the environment without it being terribly obvious, and could have been used better, but where it was used, it was alright. With a longer game and better level design, it might have been better.
The bad attempts:
Voice acting. This wasn't the worst, but it was absolutely along mediocre lines. The main character, who with more development might have proved interesting, was especially average. Her partner in crime, Scoot, was somewhat better, but not by much.
Platforming. This is probably the most offensively poor part of the game, I think. When it works properly, it's passable, but when it fails due to needing to be very precise, it's just frustrating. Fortunately there were only maybe three spots that made this especially noticeable in the game, but that's three too many, in my book.
Game length. I'm not sure how this game's development went, if it was extended over and over to get the water simulation down or what, but the end result was much too short and the most unique gameplay element introduced way too late. Even trying to find everything in the game in a single pass (which to be fair I didn't manage), I beat it in about 4 hours. For $5 that's not too bad, and on sale for $.50 that's especially okay, but you probably won't find yourself replaying it.

reviewText:
I bought this game a long time ago when I saw it on sale for next-to-nothing.  I was really shocked at the quality in this super-budget title!

In the game you play a female protagonist in her linear adventure in a floating city. She is led through the bowels of the city's utility systems by a male co-worker who speaks in her earpiece.  He is watching most everything you do via the many security cameras in the city.  The exchanges are quite humorous now and then (and one time VERY humorous!).  The city is under attack from a villianess-of-the-week and her many rent-a-thugs.

The game has controls similar to the Tomb Raider reboot although not quite as polished.  It also has Batman Arkham Assylum Detective vision for solving some simple puzzles.  The game also throws in some Half-Life 2 styled electricity and water puzzles.

The thing that impressed me the most in this game are the water physics.  If the developer is reading this, my hat is off to you my friend.  The water physics are -=AMAZING=-!  The best I have seen in ANY videogame!

Gun combat is not great but passable.  Fortunately this little missy is very tough and can take quite a few hits.  Combat in flooded rooms adds a new dimension as enemies are difficult to see on the other side of the water's surface.  I was frequently diving and surfacing to keep up with the enemies as they appeared above and below the water-line.

I have not finished the game but I believe I am very close.  It is a short game, maybe 8 hours.  I read in the forums the final boss fight is a pain.

PROS:

+ -=Excellent=- value for your money.
+ Novel gunplay situations in flooded areas.
+ Varied gameplay from platforming to combat to environmental puzzles.
+ THE FREAKING WATER PHYSICS!  Holy crap it is amazing!!
+ Occasionally amusing banter between the main characters
+ Documents and objects to collect along the way if you are into that.
+ Graphics are quite good for a budget title.

CONS:

- Platforming is a little rough around the edges.  Character animations are a little stiff at times.
- Environments can get a little samey as you make your way through the maintinence chambers under the city (where most of the game takes place).
- While the main character looks nice, some of the other character models do not look so good.
- Some of the environmental (Half Life 2 style) puzzles will test your patience.  These just aren't as fun as they were in the mid-2000's.

The game is not perfect, but the value you get for the price is outstanding.  It would be worth a go at twice the asking price.  If you enjoyed the Tomb Raider reboot, this game is a no-brainer!

reviewText:
Do you want to be an all-powerful water mage fighting a one woman war on eco-terrorists? Then this game may just be for you.

I started playing this game with low hopes but was surprised at times and disappointed at others. There were of course a few fun things and a couple of moments that stood out above the rest as memorable. At the begining I really enjoyed myself yet it was mostly downhill from there. The water mechanics and powers later on were awesome to play with. But for the most part this game was meh.

The combat is bland and forgetful, the weapons for the most part were serviceable and the supernatural abilities, although fun to use, only come into play towards the very end of the game. Also the plot, from what little there was, appeared rushed and had a very weak payoff.

I wouldn’t recommend this game at full price, but at the low low sale price of 47 pence or 60 cents then there are worse things you can buy.

Have fun. ^_^

reviewText:
The water looks fantastic, and there are a lot of really good elements to this game, but there are some unfortunate killer flaws that bring me to not recommend it.
The first and most important issue is there is a point in the game you simply can not go past due to a design issue.  Forums indicate that this is somewhat random and may be passable by messing with video settings.  The problem there is your card/driver/settings should never impact the mechanics of the game, and the issue is a jump that can't be made due to distance.  Very odd, and it was the nail in the coffin for this one.
Up until that point I almost had to stop playing it several times because the number one way the game lives up to it's name is by making you sea sick.  The camera follow is abysmal, whipping around randomly as you go in and out of water, up and down from ladder to platform, and even just trying to swim around under water.  The violent thrashing of the camera, and some times inability to look past a very confined point when you need to look around is just terrible.

Had those two issues been addressed in the years since release, it would at least be an enjoyable play with some engaging visuals.  It has a good balance of strategic shooter and light puzzle solver familiar to other games of the genre.

Past that however, you note a couple other problems.  For one, it's very short.  Given what I read from those who were able to play the whole game, the killer point I mentioned is quite near the end.  That means the total play time is 4 hours or less.  Also, while they clearly had a great back story to the game world, very little of it is shared in the game.  This leads you to feel lost while things are being talked about in a very matter of fact way.  While not entirely unusual in similar games, the fact that bad guys just appear out of nowhere with no reason (didn't come in by door, just popped up) is off putting.  It's also quite obvious the bad guys must have gills, because unlike you they can stay under water indefinitely.  There is also the matter of the water control powers.  Apparently you get those right at the end, so I never got to experience them, but saving something like that for the last 20 minutes of the game?  Odd choice in my opinion.  In the end, other than the sea sickness there really is never a sense of fear of the water, which makes one wonder if there was an element the developers just failed to convey given the implied back story.

All told, if you take a sea sick pill and get the game on a super steam sale for $1, it will pass a couple hours, and how hard can you complain for $1?  Well, I guess about as hard as this review...

reviewText:
You like video games? You like realistic water physics? Ever seen a game with realistic water physics? If you answered yes to either of the first two questions then this is the game for you! If you answered yes to the third question, please let me know what game has realistic water physics other than this one, because I have never found another game with this much detail that doesn't lose performance with the water physics. This game has had a special place in my heart, ever since I first discovered it on Xbox 360 back before I had a PC. I highly recommend this game!

FYI:
If you were wondering about why I only have 3 hours in this game, that is because the entire game is beatable in that short of a time period. However it does have a free-mode where you can play a sort of wave survival gamemode and really play with the water physics!

reviewText:
Hydrophobia is a game in which attempts to evoke Under Siege mixed with Tomb Raider and brings elements from Watch Dogs and Psi-Ops.

… but it does a terrible job of doing all of those things.

I thought going in this would be a smaller budget title with light platforming and puzzle solving.. mostly using water. I was wrong. Its pretty much just a shooter. That wouldn't be a bad thing if it were good at that. The mechanics of shooting just barely qualify as competent. The nicest things I can say about the game are as follows:

- The swimming isn't completely busted
- The cut-scenes actually seem decent as if someone actually spent time on those.
- There are multiple types of ammo (none of which feel good)
- Its easier to tell when people are dead underwater
- The game ends eventually.

I have no idea what compelled me to play this until the credits were rolling. I guess mostly because I had already invested some time and Howlongtobeat.com said I didn't have much further to go. So I suffered through the injustice in the name of due diligence.

The voice acting isn't awful either but its certainly far from being good. If you really like B list Sci Fi original movies then this will be right up your alley but if not just stay clear.

reviewText:
By the gods, those water effects!I see alot of people complaining about this game, its bugs and/or lag, but so far i found none, maybe they have crappy computers and don`t know.
The game is actually quite good, and the storyline is pretty great too, although it needs work.
I also like the weapons and their ideas, but by the gods those water effects though, figures that a game with the name hydrophobia would contain water, but didn`t expect THAT much, but those effects though, hmm hmm.
You can also shoot certain windows/glass and/or open doors to let water in or out of a room, which its a pretty great mechanic i must say.
I also like the leading lady role(female protagonist), and although some may disagree, i think if it was a guy the game wouldn`t be as good, but hey, its just me.
In my opinion, there should more games like this, but with less water......and with more bang bang, and a guy named Bustin Jieberes so i can shoot him hehehe.
All and all, a great game where water is the main subject, and for you to start facing your fear of water, or just if you have nothing else to play, or if you like female protagonists, girl power!

reviewText:
This game is often on sale for $0.99 or less, and at that price, I think it is definitely worth it.

There are a lot of negative reviews for this game, and they aren't entirely wrong, but I don't think it's a terrible game. It has its ups and its downs and a full load of meh. So, let's break it down. Warning: Minor spoilers, but nothing that really gives away the story.

Positives:
- The water physics: they are definitely cool and a major positive. I wish more games would make such use of flowing water physics to affect the characters and environment. It is fun to use water flooding to disorient your enemies and sweep them off their feet, it's neat how the intensity, direction, and depth of the water flow affect your own movement and so on. In some cases, you can see flooded compartements behind glass barriers, and if you shoot out the glass, that water floods into an area to have several effects. Similarly, some destructable leaky bulkheads can be shot out for similar effects, in some areas even completely filling the corridors and compartments you are in, which can be a danger but finding an air-pocket is usually not too hard.
- Use of the environment as weapons: not just the water, but leaky gas pipes, explosive panels and barrels, electrical panels and wires... all can be used strategically to trap and take out groups of bad guys.
- The Mavi" device: I found the way you can use it to scan and control somethings in the environment as well as see invisible messages and such pretty nifty. Not awesome
recommended:
but cool enough.

Negatives:
- The voice acting: it's very weak
hoursPlayed: and I'll be surprised if you don't find the main character's voice to be whiny and annoying.\n- The keyboard and mouse controls: if you play this game
voteText: you'll definitely want to do it with a controller. Controlling with a keyboard and mouse is just really wonky. It's not perfect with a gamepad but it is much better and will save you a lot of frustration
helpfulPercent:
especially later in the game when it comes to controlling water.
- The final boss battle is pretty terrible and frustrating until you figure out what to do. It's darned near impossible with keyboard/mouse controls.

The meh:
- The story is really weak. It wanted to be something good
votesHelpful: but the writers didn't pull it off well.\n- The gameplay in general. It's not terrible but it isn't very good either. It tries to combine a lot of things: cover-based shooting
votesFunny: and a bit of "magic" in the form of a nanobot infection giving you the ability to somewhat control the water. But it doesn't do any of these these things particularly well.\n- The challenge room is pretty dull (unlocked upon completing the game)
commentsCount: and the gameplay is not good enough to make it much fun. Only worth playing if you must go for 100% achievements.\n\nThis game doesn't do a lot
column16: so don't expect a lot. It wanted to be something amazing and utterly failed at that
column17: but there is fun to be had.  I think you can easily get several hours of enjoyment out of it for $0.99 when it's on sale
column18: but don't go in with high expectations and you won't find yourself being too disappointed. Again
column19: playing it with a controller is pretty much a must."

reviewText:
This game wasn't bad at all and the game really focuses on water effects and how it acts. Just like how it was in Bioshock.

The game keeps you moving along and it can get directionally challenging to find your way sometimes. There is an in game map and its a 3D modeling of the complex your in.

There is lots of voice acting in the game and your computer pad screen that you use like xray scanning around the area to find codes and messages help you to find your way point for where to go.

Overall the game isn't bad and somewhat interesting, when it goes on sale for around $2.49 its worth picking up.

reviewText:
This game looks promising, and could have potential, but ends up wasting what it has with clunky controls and with just how short the game is.

First off, the good points. The graphics are very good, especially the water and the way it flows between rooms. The near-future sci-fi setting is above-average and shows quite a bit of promise.

Unfortunately, the bad points significantly outweight the good for this game. The controls need quite a bit of work. For simply walking around they're fine, but the jumping controls are extremely spotty. I died far too many times because the character wouldn't jump or would jump the wrong direction. Also, the cover system doesn't work consistenly (won't always go into cover when you need it, randomly can't shoot around corners, sometimes randomly jumps out of cover) which makes some of the firefights later in the game quite frustrating.

The sci-fi setting, as interesting as it is, is woefully underutilized. The game supposedly takes place on a floating city, but you never actually see it (the quick glimpse out the window at the beginning notwithstanding). For all I know this could be in a secret underwater base or in tunnels deep below a conventional city.

The water powers are a cool concept, but the clunky controls combined with the fact that you don't actually get them until almost the end of the game and that there is only really one power was a big letdown since it was one of the selling points of the game for me.

Finally, the biggest weakness of this game is just how short it is. I blew through it in 4 hours without a walkthrough and with dying a significant number of times due to the controls. There is no closure on the story (unless it's in a hidden video after the credits). Sure, you stop the bad guys, but what happens to the city?

I feel like the concepts behind this game are solid, the setting and the basic gameplay ideas are spot on, but the poor execution and lack of content really hurts this game.

Unfortunately this game is from 2011 and it's been a long time since the last update so I'm not confident that there will be any further improvements. Not recommended.

reviewText: I finished this game to get my money's worth, but it's not even worth it free.  It's not worth the emotional trauma because everything about it is terrible.  Terrible story, terrible characters, terrible voice acting, awful controls and pointless time trials.  I even encountered a bug where the final boss won't spawn lol. Thankfully the reload point wasn't too far off.  The final boss battle was very frustrating and gave no sense of satisfaction once it was over.\n\nThe only good thing about this is of course the water physics.  Next time I want to see good water physics, I'll go to the beach instead. Lesson learned, not all 90% off games are worth buying!

reviewText:
Having bought this for $2 or somesuch ages ago, I'm stunned at how good this game is. The flaws -- mostly m+kb control-related for me -- need no pointing out, and were apparently pretty glaring on first release, but it was expanded and improved, and I'll list the high points that really stand out for me:

1) Story and plot development. The slow way the player is introduced to the world of HP is just fantastic. No big cinematic intro or information dump on who your character is or where you are, and it's only through small details like pictures or found documents that some background is unveiled. When the bombs start going off, you're just as clueless as your character, rushing around to put out the next fire or repair a sub-system. I'm really impressed with how well the plot unrolled, how involved I became with the character, and still think about the unanswered questions.

2) Graphics and water effects. Great stuff. Much of the gameplay revolves around the excellent and ever-present water effects, and I became just as anxious as the character about drowning.

3) The 'Mavi' device; what a nice in-game tool: A tablet-like device that your character holds up, and that displays an enhanced wireframe view of your surroundings, with objectives and points-of-interest highlighted. An intuitive and well-designed HUD element, that's only there when your character deploys it; every time I used it I congratulated the devs on thinking it up.

Well, those are enough. For $2 & a short 7 hour campaign, there's more than enough reasons to give Hydrophobia Prophecy some attention. Runs fine under Win8.

reviewText:
I'd like to think there was a really grat idea... that was just never fully realized, or they just didn't quite know how they wanted to effectively pull it off. See, it's one thing to advertise a game with having an ability, but it's another to save this until the last chunk of the game.

There are some well implemented ideas, unfortunately, none of which go well with what the intended vision might have been. Combat mechanics are awkward, some of the controls a tad unresponsive, and you're never completely clear on exactly how you're supposed to accomplish certain tasks. Oh, and you'll likely die a lot from trial and error trying to either figure out how to solve a puzzle, or drowning. Usually the latter.

I like the cover mechanics, although it's probably best to stick with the Sonic Rounds, since not only are they the highest accuracy, but they also don't have ammo, and you charge them. And you can use them underwater. Of course, your enemies can use shotguns underwater... which is kind of cheap if you ask me.

I wouldn't say this is a terrible game, as there are elements that do work... sort of, but I probably wouldn't recommend this, unless they decided they really, really wanted to try this.

[SPOILERS]

Now... if they had allowed you to use your waterbending" powers a lot sooner

reviewText:
Hydrophobia is a puzzle/action/platformer akin to games like Tomb Raider, Prince of Persia, Legacy of Kain and countless other titles that we have probably played at one point or another. It's extremely atmospheric and it's got great visualizations (particularly the water effect- no kidding, right?) and sound. Here's the break down:

THE GOOD: Stuff I liked.

1. The Water
The water is, as the name implies, the cornerstone of this game. It is the reason for the game's interesting atmosphere and environment based puzzles. The physics, graphics and visualizations (movement of waves, transition from surface to underwater, water on camera, etc) are superb. Best water effects I've seen in a game. Period.

2. The Environment Interaction/ Movement
I really enjoyed the layout of the levels and their design in general. There was a decent mix of swimming and climbing, giving each zone a level of depth that I don't often notice in other games (save for some of the ones I mentioned previously). Or maybe it's just because I was actually able to interact with it to such a high degree that made it interesting. This includes shooting out glass doors, blasting through bulkheads and raising the ambient water level. Very cool experience.

3. NAVI Mechanic
I really enjoyed the NAVI mechanic. The protagonist comes equipped with a transparent PDA gadget that acts as your GUI in the game, keeping all your notes, grants access to your in game menus, highlights secret messages in the game and enables you to do all your non-combat trickery (hacking, opening doors, etc).

4. PRICE!!! $$$!!
I think I bought the game on sale for $0.50? So in the end it was money well spent. ^_^



The BAD: Stuff that was 'Meh.'

1, Clunky Movement
So, while you can do all this neat stuff like roll, climb, swim and cling to cover... the controls felt somewhat unresponsive. Often I'd lose the ability to shoot around cover and have to back off and re-cling to get it working again. Likewise, occasionally the game would ignore a command to dive, roll, or jump. The fact that it occurred sporadically made it that much more of an aggravation when these missed commands would pop up... particularly in a heated, combat situation!

2. *Occasional* Camera Angles from Hell
Again, these didn't happen very often but when they did it was really difficult to get out of them. It most often happened while swimming and most usually in tight corridors. Of course, this is a typically problem of any game with a high degree of mobility in a given environment.

3. Backtracking
I don't mind a whole lot of backtracking personally. Given the NAVI's ability to help you perceive new things in the environment and the changing level of water, I'd rank this game about equal with such games as Legacy of Kain and Chrono Trigger. OF COURSE, there's backtracking... the designers want to show you how a place has changed. So I don't think it's a problem, but a lot of other reviews did.

4. 'Easy' Combat...?
I played the game on Normal mode and died a total of 2 (maybe 3?) times while in combat. The badguy AI is fairly responsive in my opinion: when you don't shoot at it, they sneak closer to you. When you do, they scramble for cover. They try to flank you, etc, etc. They don't do any of this quickly, but they do it. They also deal enough damage that you can't go barreling in guns blazing very often either.

But, if you're like me and you rock the sneaky/cautious/clever game style, you'll probably breeze through the game since there's ample opportunity for you to use environmental hazards to your advantage. This is NOT Call of Duty, Counterstrike, or anything resembling a real" shooter. It just happens you can shoot things.

5. Voice Acting
I've seen a lot of bad reviews because of voice acting... but honestly
date: I've heard a LOT worse (none come to mind this instant
recommended: but we've all heard worse). Plus
hoursPlayed:
there's not a whole lot of it. I actually think the worst voice acting comes mainly from the protagonist (which is unfortunate) because I thought the acting of the antagonist and your plucky tech support ally were decent enough (if not reading from a very unimaginative script).




THE UGLY: Stuff that's unforgivable (imho).

In order
voteText:
1. Repetitive game play and goals.
The whole game is about finding keys to locked doors
helpfulPercent:
almost without exception. This sucks. I'm just glad the environment was fun to navigate to make me forget that this was all I was doing. Blah.

2. Very few upgrades/collectables/etc.
You pick up about 3 'new' abilities that you use sporadically throughout the game. There was also about 6 different types of ammo you could collect... but you really never needed it until the end of the game. This is one extremely crucial difference between this game and the likes Legacy of Kain and Prince of Persia (also games like Metroid

3. INCREDIBLY SHORT GAME!

Overall

reviewText: Quite a few people seem to be giving this game bad reviews, and honestly i can't see why. Personally I had a great time playing this game and it was alot more than I had expected for the price. The game mechanics and controls are great, in fact they're alot better than most games i've played. Shooting while hiding behind cover was well done, and I enjoyed the underwater gunfights. Another thing i liked about this game was the hacking system which is simple but effective. Needless to say, the water looked awesome and the physics to go along with it worked well. The game looked and played amazingly, and the voice acting was passable. The only issue I had was a bit of frame rate drop near the end of the game, which is understandable considering all the water physics. Overall I throughly enjoyed this title, and consider it one of the better game purchases i've made. I find myself wishing there were a sequel, as not many affordable games turn out as great as this one. Would definately recommend!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Seeing this game on sale often at $1.24, I decided to take a chance, thinking how bad can it really be? So, going in with my expectations low I was surprised to find an OK game here.

While HP has several flaws, none of them are game braking or frustrating, other than the occasional micro stutter which can be distracting. Being a huge Tomb Raider fan I see it's influence here and can only guess that the dev team wanted to make a TR game in water. While the TR-ish foundation is there, the puzzle solving, jumping and climbing, and combat, all of these are under utilized and so sporadic that most of the time you're just left to play in the water, which is the main focus of the game anyway. Although I have to admit, the effect is kind of cool...YAY!! *splash splash*

Overall, the lite game play elements/mechanics are done just well enough without feeling like a chore and I did find the game enjoyable enough even with the barely there story and the meh voice acting. Surprisingly, it actually kept me entertained enough to finish the game in one sitting. If you're a TR fan or enjoy that type of gameplay, I would say give it a try at $1.24, you could do worse with your money.

reviewText:
My friend bought me this title for 49 cents. I did not expect much, but at least the game met those expectations.

It is the start of a new century. The story follows a young women named Jane Wilson, a surprisingly fit lady who works for a nano-robotics company. It is revealed at the start of the game that she is hydrophobic, which is ironic, since this game involves lots and lots of swimming (more on that later). She needs to stop a terrorist organisation focused on destroying her workplace and everything it stands for. The gameplay brings nothing new to the table. It is a third-person shooter, with a single weapon but with multiple types ammunition. The most useful ammotype in the game (and arguebly the most powerful) is the sonic blasts. Unfortunatly this renders the other ammotypes nigh useless, creating a great imbalance in the gameplay. As I said previously, the game involves alot of swimming. While underwater, I often found myself fighting the unintuitive controls. There is a mechanic which restricts the amount of time the player can spend underwater, before returning to the surface for air. One can also get involved in bouts of underwater combat, which is less exciting than it sounds.

Speaking of combat, overall, it is definitely on the feeble side. The best way to clear out enemies, that I have found, (keeping in mind that I played it on hard) is to headshot them with sonic blasts from behind cover. This is not really a game where run and gun tactics are that effective. Taking cover is always your safest bet. In general the combat is not that difficult   and can be quite repetitive. The game uses an interesting way of pointing you towards objectives. The player uses a transparent tablet-like device and holds it infront of the screen. This presents a sort of augmented reality that indicates the location of objectives. This device is also used for hacking. Hacking is more rudimentary than it sounds and is just used to open doors and hack security camaras. Sometime the player needs to hack control panels. This involves a minigame, where the mouse is used to control the amplitude and the wavelength of a wave. The player needs to match these variables to those of a another wave. This is also very easy, but surprisingly fun (I am a bit of a geek :-) ).

And then there are the powers. The pictures of this game leads one to believe that they are an integral part of gameplay. Unfortunately they are not. The powers are only introduced near the end of the game. Making the players experience with them far to short to justify their existence. Speaking of too-short, this game can be completed in six hours if you are playing on hard difficulty. And much quicker on the easier ones. This is much too short for my taste and makes me feel that the developers shouldn't have released this game in its current state.

Now for the million dollar question (or whatever you pay for the game)
Is it worth it?
For 5$, no.
For 1$, yes.

I give it 5\10

reviewText: It's an indie game and you can see it was created on a tight budget as the ending feels a bit rushed for my taste. Nevertheless is it a surprisingly good game with some interesting approaches to gameplay mechanics e.g. hacking terminals and of course the phantastic water. As you'll do a lot of platforming it is worth mentioning that the movement controls are solid. As Hydrophobia was first released on XBLA it supports Xbox controller although playing with keyboard and mouse is no problem at all. What you get on steam is a reworked version of the game with better graphics and one different character model with new voice acting - I like the original scottish accent better. Please compare Xbox vs Pc version on youtube. The game code feels not very optimized for Pc . I play titles like Metro Last Light or Crysis 3 with ease in max settings in 1920x1200 while my HD 7950 doesn't get noisy whereas Hydrophobia seems quite taxing in max settings. So if you own an older pc or a low spec laptop you may be forced to turn down the graphics settings.Checkpoints are well placed and fair meaning you don't have to replay lengthy sequences if you're dying. The only bug I noticed was a clipping error in chapter 2. You will get  as average gamer 6 hours of gameplay out of it.\nIf you're asking yourself if it is worth buying - definitely. If it's on sale you can get it for a few cents so why would you miss out on it? There are  choices far worse you could make. My conservative rating is a solid 7 out of 10.

reviewText:
One of the best indie games I've played, all things considered.
It is kind of like Syphon Filter + Assassin's Creed (because parkour/climbing).

One of the most heart-breaking games ever; such an anti-climactic ending.
The developer went under (pun intended). There will be no sequels.

Not sure why people love to rip the game to shreds. The combat is tight, the story is pretty cool. The voice acting is somewhat dreadful and the game does end with you saying WTF." It's a testament of Man; that development studio poured themselves into the game. Was not well-received. The company was dissolved (er

reviewText: This game is 4 years old, but I have yet to see water simulated this realistically in any AAA title to date. The game has some issues. Controls don't work very well, and the writing of the characters kills the immersion. I don't know if the dev was trying to recreate the mixture of realism and humor that Valve is known for, but it just doesn't work. Would love to see this physics engine employed in a better game. Voice acting is for the most part quite good. All that said, I'm recommending this game only if it's on sale. It's not worth $4.99, even as pretty as it is.

reviewText:
Hydrophobia: Prophecy is 3rd person survival-horror style action-adventure game. While the PC keyboard/mouse controls are fine, the game also has platforming elements, as well - so, I wound up using the X360 Controller for this one.

While the graphics are not spectacular, they are good & do get the job done just fine here. The water looks stunning. The voice-acting is good, though the story could use a little more kick & depth to it. The water in this game is its own creature, as it will effect the environment & its surrounding - especially since feels like it has weight to it. Using the environment for combat is another thing that makes this game stand out, since you really don't have very many weapons or skills at your disposal...until later on in the game.

When it's all said & done, Hydrophobia: Prophecy is a pretty good start to what looks to be a series that could have a lot of potential, if they keep on building on the nice foundation that this game actually sets.

Grade = B-

On the other side we have well-made water physics, really cool using water as weapon ( sadly in last missions) and the most important - shooting. There is no place for cowards here. You are going straight forward, shooting to enemies with bullets, explosives and sometimes other upgreads for our gun. Ii took me 3 hours to finish this game. I dont regret money or time spent on this game. If u will see it on sale, dont think, just buy it. It is worth its pirce.

reviewText: Still a good looking game. Short, but fun. Can be a bit buggy if you're after the in-game medals (for achievements), but no major issues. Played on Windows 10 Pro x64 without any problems.\n\nWorth picking up on sale.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
tl;dr:
Play this for... awesome water effects, nice atmosphere and story, varied gameplay
Accept... controls that are a little fiddly sometimes, especially during shootouts (gamepad)
Be prepared... for the plot to rush to a sudden, pretty unsatisfiying ending from a certain point
---

First, look and physics of the water are simply incredible and contribute a lot to the nice atmosphere of the game. I was really impressed especially by the movement of the water and the fluent (haha...) way the character reacts to it.

This game includes climbing passages (solid and fun), cover mechanic shootouts (a little fiddly sometimes), some riddles (rather easy, but some are original) and more... Overall game duration does not offer enough time to exploit the potential of all gameplay mechanics (e.g. different ammunition types are almost irrelevant)

I play games like this primarily for the story, but attach a lot of value on gameplay and controls.
Controls feel a little clumsy in certain situations, but are fine overall.
The plot starts out and evolves nicely ... up to one point. Then all of a sudden the story kind of collapses and then rushes to a sudden end, leaving a lot unanswered. This felt really disappointing and left me very unsatisfied. However, remembering the early phases of the game I still recommend this game for its atmosphere, water effects and varied gameplay.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Despite all the negative comments I've received about this game, I actually quite liked 'Hydrophobia Prophecy'. The environment and art direction was exactly what I was hoping for. The futuristic cityscape and impressive water effects go together very well indeed! The controls were a little bit wonky during the final parts of the game, but it's still a very fun time. It's a short three-act story, which was supposed to be continued in future instalments. Unfortunately, this is looking unlikely at the moment. It's a bit of a shame, in my opinion; so many questions were set up for the potential sequels only to end on a cliffhanger. What a waste for the HydroEngine. The water was so very pretty.

reviewText:
Giant ship. Terrorists. You save the day. In 3 short acts.

Not hugely overwhelming, but still very nice 3rd person climbing/shooting/swimming game with female protagonist.

Compares somewhat to Tomb Raider, though the balance between jumping around and fighting is shifted more towards the latter. And there's lots of swimming. Water is literally everywhere. In the endgame you can do some funky stuff with it, pity that doesn't last long before game ends.

The whole game pretty much is a showcase of their water simulation engine and you really gotta hand it to them, I haven't seen better looking water anywhere else. The waves, overflowing... Nice looking game!

The voice acting of the main protagonist is rather off, though you can assume it's some foreign accent. The only real spite I have is with some medals bugging out if you die while getting them so you have to repeat parts of game (explorer, flood), or even turn off cloud and reinstall (deep breath, apparently?!). Harsh achievement.

reviewText:
Don't let the price fool you, its a fun game! The water effects are quite well done, there is some innovative mechanics (having to balance the character when she walks across beams for example) and some good level design.

The downsides? You can tell its a budget title, the facial animations aren't as good as a AAA and you can tell there are some mechanics that needed more polish like the hacking.

If you can get it for $5 or less? Its a good buy, it will give you your money's worth.

The security friend guiding you sounds like he's from some 90's narrated arcade game, the woman they hired to voice act actually managed to portray the quality of cardboard in her voice acting... She literally sounds like a cardboard being, not a human being just... Cardboard. Awful this woman should never work in voice acting again, it was just horrific.

reviewText:
Not bad for 39p!
It's short, lacks gameplay and has a fair few bugs, but for the price you can't really complain.
The water effects looks quite nice (especially considering the game is 4 years old) and it's something to pass the time.
As others have said, it's more like a tech demo than a game as the gameplay mechanics are so basic and the combat very simplistic.
Has the potential to be something nice if they can make a proper full game out of it and polish it up a bit.
I'm ticking 'Yes' to recommend simply because it is what it is, and if that is all you're expecting then you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: Impressive for an indie game. Like any TOMBORAIDAR, you regularly have to struggle with camera/control clunkery (water hits you? controls bork; at the point between 'above water' and 'under water', the controls and the camera just do what they want), some jumps are a bit annoying, f.ex. when it's unclear how much of the area you can jump off of you can still use as ramp and then if you jump early you fall and die and get to re-climb some dumb walls, and if you jump la... waaaaah abyss. But it's definitely worth the very little money it costs here, you'll get some jolly hours out of it.

reviewText:
You can now (07/03/2014) save 90% on this gem! I believe you should all proceed as you're not gonna regret it!

Dark Energy's Hydrophobia is an action-adventure game that takes place in an underwater city. This is what the game's antagonists (terrorists) are trying to get rid of by placing bombs at several places to have it completely destroyed by water.

Now, here comes the interesting part: Kate, the girl you control, can manipulate water. While you have the usual cover-shoot-cover-style gameplay you also have the option to move water - this looks and feels amazing thanks to the technology incorporated in the game that makes sure handling water is as fluid and dynamic as possible.

The game can be difficult at times and being an indie game it does not have top-notch voice-acting. Also, being an indie game it is rather short - doing a complete walkthrough can be managed in 3 or 4 hours. Nevertheless, I recommend this game especially due to the regular discount it receives - another proof why we should look for some indie titles in between those AAA titles.

reviewText:
Not that bad at all. So, I wouldn't say this good, but this definitely is not bad.
First, the story and setting is nice. The overall shooting gameplay as well. I just wanted to play with water more in story.
Second, games should not be judged by their length. This one is just ~3-4 hours long, but if it would be 8 hours long, we all could see that developers just wanted to put stuff in it, so their game is longer. I respect them for not doing it and revealing all their ideas without putting silly stuff in as well.
So buy while it's on 90% discount. You won't want to pay full price for such a short game.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you play Hydrophobia expecting a full game, you'll likely be disappointed.  It's not very long, and it doesn't have a proper ending or wonderful plot, and it does have some fiddly bits.

However, if you go into it expecting a tech demo, I think you'll be much more impressed.  The water effects are great and create a great atmosphere.  You also have an augmented reality tablet which allows some interesting mechanics.  Overall it's a fun world to dip into for a bit.  I wish the developers had had the opportunity to continue the story and polish out the rough spots.

Even at full price I think Hydrophobia Prophecy is worth purchasing, though not by a wide margin.  However, it's frequently on sale very cheap ($0.49 at time of writing), which makes it easy to recommend if the water effects catch your eye.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A novel fps game with a cool water and physics system. There are only around 3 hours of play in the main campaign but it is enjoyable and intriguing. The control system can be quite clunky at times, especially when in deep water, but the shooting and cover systems work well. It's a 7.5 out of 10. Not totally amazing brilliant, but if you are looking for something a little quirky from your action fps, give it a shot.

reviewText:
This game is a must buy if you enjoy all aspects of water!

I did hit a few game breaking bugs near the middle (which is to be expected of any well made game), but when I quit and came back to the game later on, and my saves had been deleted forcing me to start again, I was like yeeeeaaahh!! that solves that issue! I also heard talk of there being a few problems with the elemental physics, like the random placement of electricity or the amount of fire in the water, but you have to ask yourself, why wouldn't a big ship-city be filled full of oil and napalm, and have exploding barrels in every room?

I'd also like to thank the makers for giving me the opportunity to hate the characters of this game with such passion! from their horrible grinding voices and the way they move, right through to their terrible (or just never mentioned) back stories. The people who made this game must have worked so hard!

I read a few bad reviews, but come on guys, I know there's been a lot of complaints about the special powers that you only get to fight the last boss with, which I know is one of the reasons you bought this game, but you did get 5 minutes to play with the powers in that moving blocks to make a bridge room on the way there, so don't be greedy!  and while we are talking about it, I thought the pushing 4 buttons at once system (using the controller), to use your water magic gave us excellent control, and the lack of a tutorial for how you use them just made the game delightfully challenging, like when I fell down that elevator shaft to my death 20 times in a row.

When I first started playing and found that it was just another game based around a silly gimmick with boring linear fps and cliche wall climbing gameplay and rubbish graphics that was made to demonstrate their water physics engine to prospective buyers, I was disappointed, but by the end when I'd pulled out all my hair and was crying into my hands, I really began to appreciate this game.

reviewText:
At first I must say that I don't like this genre too much (I prefer games like this being first person) but I got this game on discount and I really think it's worth the money.

The graphics are fluent and there is nothing about it that could tell you it's just an indie game. I personally found it more exciting than the last few AAA games of this genre I encountered.

I only think it could have used more adventure elements but for a shooter I think it's ok.

What is really fresh about this game is the setting. I haven't seen anything like this yet and as I was always a lover of movies like Deepstar Six" or "The Abyss" the water and / or underwater setting is quite appealing to me.

The sound and music are both top of the notch. I'd say this game is a mix of "Tomb Raider" and "Deus Ex" but without the hassle.

This game is worth it's price even if it's not on sale!"
