reviewText: I was actually really liking this game, and ready to give it a rather positive review, until I encountered by far one of the ♥♥♥♥-poorest final boss battles in GAMING HISTORY.  First of all, it's the ONLY boss battle in the entire game.  Secondly, it's at least two to three times harder than any other part OF the game, and requires the mastery of a completely new skill you only gain ten minutes beforehand.  Thirdly, it appears to have no checkpoints throughout its excruciating length.  Fourthly, it's inconsistent as a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and what worked the last time won't necessarily work the next (half the time I successfully threw explosives at the boss robot, the other half I merely succeeded in blowing MYSELF up).  All I can say is: THANK GOD FOR YOUTUBE.  Oh, and your reward for beating the boss?  One of the briefest and most abrupt (and I don't mean John Carpenter's The Thing" kinda enigmatic; I really do just mean ABRUPT) end cut scenes ever.  Rarely before have I witnessed a final fifteen minutes of a game which seemed so...tacked on
date:
and thoroughly unsatisfying.


And maaaaan...I was really looking forward to defending this game against all the naysayers.  I'm still gonna thumb it up and give it a reasonable score
recommended: but ONLY because it was so enjoyable (borderline ENTHRALLING

reviewText:
This game was not fun to start out. It thrusts you into the world with a lot of loud noises and commotion. After that, it simmers, even though it sounds crazy.
All the back story is done through documents you find throughtout the game, which is not how you tell a story.
The story is pretty lackluster... Until the last act when you get the weird blue thing. Then things kinda get interesting! They start teasing this thing caled S.A.R.A., you hear weird things in the water, and it feels funner, more challenging.
You get powers and then its really interesting! You fight the final boss, you kill the big bad?, and then you are cured.
Smash cut to the points screen. Nothing is resolved. You know nothing. Nothing was gained. You didn't change.
I feel like this game had 6 hours cut from it, for some odd reason.
But I guess the water is cool? When it's not glitching. Like everything else.

reviewText:
Hydrophobia: Prophecy is a 3rd person action game by Dark Energy Digital. The game has some amazing water physics, but unfortunately that is all it really has going for it. The game play is mediocre and the platforming that the games throws at you is not very good. The graphics are decent, but not enough to justify the frame rate drops that I would get for no apparent reason on my 7870 O.C. It seems like the game was not optimized good enough and was not able to keep a steady frame rate on a decent rig. The story was fairly interesting, but not enough to carry the game for me. The voice acting wasn’t the worst that I have heard but it was far from being any good. I played the game for about an hour and decided to retire it. Time to move on to another game in my backlog, hopefully one that is fairly good this time.

Pros:
-	Amazing water physics. Some of the best that I have seen in gaming.
-	Fairly interesting story.
-	Funny characters.

Cons
-	Poorly optimized. I had constant frame rate drops on my overclocked 7870
-	Poor voice acting for most of the characters.
-	The Platforming is not very good.
-	The combat is fairly Generic for what I have played of the game

*Please note that I did not finish the game. I would recommend checking better sources from people who have finished*

reviewText: Hydrophobia: Prophecy is a game with the best water physics I've ever seen in a game. In fact if you are unfortunate enough you're game might have a broken hacking sytem, which is essential to get through several areas of the game. The hacking system failed so badly that I was forced to play the console version of this game because the PC copy I got was broken even though I tried everything to fix it (including reinstalling the game and even trying to edit the games files).\nEven if this goes on sale for 99% off this game is NOT worth buying, you will regreat it immediately.

This game is only has had all effort put into water physics and everything else sucks about it

This game sucks
It gets 1/10 or 2/10
Nothing more

reviewText:
Starts off really promising with an interesting setting, rather intriguing plot and the promise of unique combat.
Ends up being a cookie-cutter shooter with little extra mechanics. While the water looks rather well and the utilization is alright (the swimming mechanics I really liked, compared to many other games that make you swim and dive through areas) with the mechanics and the hydrophobia of the protagonist, hence the game's title, being displayed comprehensibly, the advertised water control mechanics only become available shortly before the game ends. Which means there is really little to be had, as the expected unique selling points are implemented poorly or just too late in the game.

The developers are bankrupt, apparently, and it seems as if they ran out of money halfway through the game. I really feel like this game was either supposed to be a trilogy or just a lot bigger. But about 2 or 3 hours in the story leaps ahead, you have a huge room where you must fight many baddies and then suddenly a boss fight, a short and unsatisfying cutscene and then ... nothing. That's it. Nothing is really concluded, nothing really happened. It seems like a prelude to the actual game, which will probably never come.

Might be worth a bargain price for the water experience, but otherwise expectations will probably fall short, as the game severely lacks substance.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: As you can guess by the obscure sources combed for positive reviews on the game's main page, Hydrophobia is almost comically bad.  The game combines dodgy controls, overambitious promises (the signature ability to control water? It's unlocked at the very end of the game), cartoonishly evil villains, and inconsistent voiceacting with a setting and plot *just* interesting enough to keep you playing.\n\nI would recommend this game to anyone studying video game design, as it is a comprehensive guide on what to avoid.

reviewText:
I tried to give this another shot. Bad idea. Don't buy it.

I once said it was not a bad game. Wrong, it is a bad game. Repetitive gameplay, useless extra powers, terrible checkpoints, terrible camera, and terrible physics. For those who really care, is also has terrible graphics, the only redeaming graphical element is the water, and it otherwise looks unimpressive.

Voice acting is also mediocure and does not help the rest of the game. The villan is utterly unimaginative and cartoonish. The collectables are pointless, so they might as well should not even be there.

I put it on easy just to get through it, even then the boss battle was brutal. As an example of the terrible checkpoint system, if you fail on this boss, once, they send back to the beginning. Even the fact that they force you to use the terrible extra mechanics in this battle make it all the more frustrating, not challenging. This is where I had to stop, I could not continue.

The level design is also really bad, clustered, and full of dead ends. If it was not for the objective markers leading me along the linear path, I would have not known where to go. Linearity is OK, but not with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ level design. This game has ♥♥♥♥♥♥ level design.

That is about all I can say on this game. I don't know the nature and resources of the dev team, but even with minimal resources a great game can be produced. This seems to me to be a project that was too big and too ambitious, and as a result just came out... bad. 10/10 for effort, 3/10 for execution.

reviewText:
Ok, there were a lot of fun things about this game. I really enjoyed the first two acts. Especially the climbing bits, and I even got to enjoy the hacking, even though it was timed.

Of course, there were quite a few reasons I'd say 'skip this game.'

The plot goes from a pace of a car to a rocket jet by the third act. Once Kate gets hydrokenisis (not a spoiler since it's in the screenshots), you barely get any time to really get how it works before you're expected to use it for the boss battle. There are a whole lot of great things about this plot that aren't given a chance to be explained. Malthusians as the terrorists, with calvinist beliefs mixed in there (calling all non-malthusians 'reprobates' meaning doomed to die), an implied overpopulation, the idea Kate is living in a ship due to that... all great ideas, but never really explored to its true potential.

I guess I wished for a first level like Half Life's, where the player wanders around Black Mesa and gets an idea of the place before everything gets crazy.

The plot summary suggests there will be character arcs, and there aren't. The only thing that changes is that Kate stops yelling whenever she has to go balance on poles. Kate's goal changes inexcplicably part-way through (I suppose her boss being killed might have something to do with it, though he was a jerk to her anyway) from ignoring curing herself and finding her friend to chasing down the bad guy.

And it just kinda... ends.

This is one of those games where the controls sometimes flat out ignore what you tell it to. Which is especially frustrating considering how unforgiving it is. (There is no saving, just checkpoints.) On that note, this was another game where the hints couldn't be turned off, and they were always brought attention to by an annoying sound.

I'm normally not bothered by voice actors, but Kate's voice actor was incredibly distracting.

The fact is, this game does a lot of things right, which makes the things it does wrong even more frustrating. What a great world to just ignore.

reviewText:
Don't let it's occasional bargain bin sale price lure you in.

For a game that takes a mere 3 hours to complete, the experience quickly becomes repetitive and shallow. Essentially a D-rate Tomb Raider clone, the gimmick here is water and how water influences the game's environments, puzzles, combat, and physics. Unfortunately, the water is overhyped and not enough to make a sub-par gaming experience worthy of your time. While the developers deserve credit for listening to player feedback and releasing two updated versions of the game after launch, the game is currently still plagued with bad design and technical issues like poor collision detection, missing textures, dumb AI, and game-breaking bugs (for some).

Gameplay and level design are outright bland. The single enemy type in the game (save for the final boss") can be easily dispatched with by using your default weapon. There are electricity and fire hazards that can be used to inflict environmental damage upon your foes
date: but the same tactics are used in every skirmish. The touted ability to control water doesn't even occur until right before the final boss
recommended: and at that point it really only seems to be there for that battle. What initially seem like clever and unique puzzles end up being recycled many
hoursPlayed: many times over the course of the game. With regards to level design
voteText: for a ship that is purported to be as large as a city
helpfulPercent: there are not many places the player gets to see that seem to have had much movement or life in them. The few room variations seen are mostly non-specific server-type rooms and innumerable hallways for the sake of filler. WIthout an in-game guide telling you where to go

reviewText: I was impressed by this game, it definitely has the coolest water/physics I have seen in a game and the story is quite fun with lots of action and exploring the environment and collectables and data to find if you enjoy that as well. The controls are pretty intuitive and it does a good job of easing you in without requiring much of a breach in immersion to explain what you need to do as it has several unique mechanics like hacking by matching wave amplitudes or using sonic bullets to break glass walls. Easily a recommend for fans of third-person action/adventure. It is a short game, split into 3 Acts of about 1 hour each, so be aware of that in your consideration.

reviewText: This is a decent game with a few problems. It's basically a first-person platformer/shooter with water - lots and lots of water. It's also very short (a few hours), so keep that in mind as well. It has a lot going for it and is definitely a cool game and concept, but the mechanics and gameplay didn't quite meet my expectations. The controls, in particular, I felt were needlessly complicated. The game also didn't run all that well on my PC, despite other more recent games running just fine. Also frustrating was the final boss fight, which was way more difficult than it should have been due to the aforementioned control problems. I also experienced game-halting bugs at more than one point in my playthrough, which could only be resolved by restarting from a checkpoint (which thankfully, are placed liberally). In summary, the overall setting and concept is cool, but it is hampered by spotty controls and a few too many bugs and glitches for my taste. Worth checking out for cheap price.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Presentation:
This game first presents itself to you with a semi-sci fi type world, I like it, anything with a futuristic sci fi world, even more so if it is original is great in my book.

You're presented with a female protagonist in this game though, I don't like most games with exclusive female playable characters so that is a bit of a problem. She has a tomboy look going on from a design aspect but that doesn't help in her case because our protagonist is annoying and generic in this game due to poor writing. Her voice actor is terrible as well. Even worse than the voice acting for females in Guild Wars 2.

So yeah, the world the game is set in looks nice and is well presented, the female protagnist though is generic and just not interesting.

Concept:
Very unique concept this game has, I like it. Water is the main elemental focus here, not many games do with the developers had in mind with this game.

However, they obviously did something very wrong since the company who made this game went bankrupt and the game engine they designed for it.

The gameplay is interesting at first, but ultimately it is just plain, bland, boring. The characters suck, Kate is a junk protagonist, her partner scoot or whatever his name is has halfway decent voice acting but he is boring as well. His animations are terrible as well.

Gameplay:
Interesting at first, gets boring though. The main aspect of the game, Water" is not used as much as it should have been

reviewText:
This game has very cool water physics effects. For instance, when you open a door, water from one room will flow into the other and be cut off once the door is shut. Then a wave will bounce back-and-forth across the room until it settles. But other than that this game is bad.

It's a standard third-person cover shooter with awful aiming. Every now in then it adds in a hacking mini-game like from the Rocksteady Batman games, or a platforming" element like Uncharted 2 & 3.

The game is riddled with sound bugs
date: where character dialogue overlaps each other
recommended:

The only unique thing about it comes in the last 10 minutes of the game when you get the ability to manipulate water. It's used for 1 puzzle and the final boss fight. That's it.

If you love fighting juggalo-looking enemies using terrible shooting mechanics

reviewText: I hate this game.  The gameplay is a boring combination of platforming and shoddy 3rd person shooting in a lame sci-fi ship setting.  I found the main character's voice acting a bit annoying sounding.  Your main weapon is a weird charging beam that one shot's all enemies when you charge it so I don't really know why there's actual ammo when you kill everything in one hit.  The game's main draw is water physics, which is underwhelming.  The water is still scripted to only fill rooms at certain parts and while not annoying, doesn't really add anything to the experience.  The graphics are subpar and the game chugs pathetically at times for no reason.  Only worth $1 or less.  The game is also only 3-4 hours long.

reviewText:
Hydrophobia is all about water *duhuh ^^*. More precicely, Hydrophobia is a water physics game, and that's about the only thing it's really good at. The awesomely looking water physics make the rest of the graphics seem like they were made 20 years ago though. Not to mention the character animations - damn, they just suck.

And story..? Well, I still have no clue what the background and main story is, other than get off that ship ASAP. I'm led through the ship by (what I guess) a collegue of mine. What's even more annoying is that you pick up a stun gun after a while, and the terrorists you meet walk around with shotguns. No problem there, but when you shoot them, you can't even opt to change weapon for their (more powerful) shotgun >:(

All I can advice is DO NOT BUY THIS GAME unless it comes in a bundle. Really, even €5 as it's priced now is still too much for this game!

reviewText:
Mixed feelings about Hydrophobia. For the price that it often goes on sale, it really can't be beat. 0.50 for some great looking graphics and atmosphere, it certainly does the trick for that much. Why people are calling it a tech demo, I don't particularly understand. It IS a full game - there is a beginning, a middle, and an end. However, I can understand that being instantly thrown into the action with little explanation could grate on peoples nerves.

I don't want to say it's Kafka-esque, because that would be giving the game far too much credit, however, the brevity of the story and the nature of it - you're more or less transformed into a bug in this huge maze and you're afraid of getting squished, I  can see some sort of draw to that sort of thing. The game does have non-stop, run faster, finishfinishfinish mentality that's lacking in many games. That doesn't always come across as a good thing.

As it's been said before, the water manipulation is a pretty cool feature, but of course it could've been done better. It is smooth in terms of being visually appealing. My biggest issue? The controls. Maybe I'm just not used to third-person games, but pretty much this is the big mood killer. It really, really will frustrate you enough to break something that can be played in a single sitting into multiple play sessions, not because you don't enjoy the game visually, but because you're sick of having to press the exact thing in the exact 0.2 second timeframe they give you to do it. At times it works, at other times, it doesn't work at all.

I give it big ups for having a female protagonist that isn't overly-sexualized. This is something people complain about all the time, and it's really not an issue here. The character is pretty, but not flawless and not the commonly associated Bimbo" flavor you have come to expect from most action games of this type. No overly enlarged breasts

reviewText:
Want nice visuals, but not so much story-wise?   This game is your best bet.

Sure the controls/gameplay is a little quirky, but the fact that this is the product of the HydroEngine, which made such beautiful water physics....HOWEVER, Dark Energy is no longer in business and this is their final project.....this is the ONLY time you'll see the HydroEngine in action.

reviewText:
I've had Hydrophobia: Prophecy in my library for a while now. I installed it this morning, beat the game in under two hours and had enough time to get ready for work... Quite frankly i'm disappointed, i was excited for a game with extremely realistic water physics, which is really the only point the game delivered on.

The game provided no backstory to the main protagonist Kate. The opening cinematic showed her in some kind of cave flooding with water, and every single time you dive under water  you hear a young girl crying and calling Kate's name.  I was hoping to progress through the game and learn more about her, and the man who pretty much guided you through the entire game, but alas, i got unending quips from him and an almost unlikeable main character.

The gunplay (if you can call it that) is mundane, you get one gun which can take 6 different types of ammo, but there are 3 you'll only ever really use. The enemies are equally as forgettable. All we know about them is that they are terrorists trying to get a hold of nano technology to wipe out the human population leaving very few faithful" survivors. We are still left wondering at the end of the game how they got on the floating city ship

reviewText: My feelings on this game are incredibly mixed. I bought it during a bargain sale when it was 0.49 euros because earlier i saw a trailer and liked it but didn't have the money. Graphics are great, no doubts there. The gameplay length is reasonably long for such a low-priced game. The water physics resemble From Dust's physics, and your character reacts to it as you would expect, you almost feel the water pushing against your body. However, the storyline is so incredibly dull that i didn't even play until the end. The combat is so simple that if you die once you truly must be new to the game. The game gives repetitive tasks and makes you walk past every place you go twice. Although it's camera hacking system has beaten Watch_dogs, you don't hack much aside from scouting the enemies and using terminals. It's only use is to find out where to shoot. It has so many enviromental ways to kill your enemies that you won't even need to shoot directly at anyone. You get a sound gun and don't even loot the enemy's guns after you kill them. All and all this game is a 7/10 at first glance, slipping to a 4/10 for repetitive and dull gameplay.

reviewText: What can I say about this game. This game tries it's hardest to make the game mechanics work like some big AAA game like Assassin's Creed, looking at the parkour mechanics, I think it actually tried mimicking Assassin's Creed. reviewText: This is an excellent game and the bad reviews are unreasonable. Other reviewers seem to be expecting some weird super hero water power. That's really stupid. reviewText:
This game is a shame, because it has a lot of interesting mechanics and ideas, but most of them are clunky, not user friendly at all. It just makes you desperate while using them.

The positive points of the game:
-Gorgeous water, graphics, physics, fluity, all the game is water related and yes, it's a nice experience.

Sadly, that's ALL the game has to offer, in my opinion.

Now, for the negative points:
-The game is insultingly short, you can easly finish it in 3 hours at best if you dont have any issues with your saved files.
-Yes, there are issues and bugs with the save files, not fixed for the time being. They go from the game not wanting to load them, to my case, where the loading screen would just stay there in an endless loop. I had to restart Act 1 and Act 2 on two sepparated occasions thanks to that.
-The plot is non-existent. The characters are bland, unappealing. 90% of the stuff that seems to be happening is never explained. Yes, there are documents scattered around, but it's not like they add much. Some videos or characters that totally seem plot-relevant, never appear again. The ending follows that half-baked fashion to the extreme. It feels like the developers had a lot of ideas for the plot and never finished one. I also cant stand the antagonists of the game, specially the main one. This is more of a personal opinion, but I think their motivations are almost ridiculous, unspired, stupid, even. Their attitude and the way they talk it's irritating. It's not because I cant stand villians being bad and cruel, but because I rather confront villians who are bad for the sake of being bad, than these kind of so half-baked ones.
-The gameplay is most of the time annoying and unresponsive. You have to swim, of course; well, it's kinda bad. Climbing it's okay. Shooting is also okay. But one mechanic you gain almost on the end of the game (shame on that too), that should be the coolest one, it's almost broken and so, you dont feel like using it. The enemies are also totally irritating. They are always saying the same sentences, dubbed by the same guy, spaming one after another, like broken toys. Being shot doesnt feel like you've been hit at all, so it's hard to track down where the bullets are coming from; sum to that the fact that in the final areas of the game, enemies wont stop popping out of god knows where, coming one after another, being sometimes more sneaky than ninjas and catching you off guard. And believe me, it's not because they've been programmed to do that. It's just buggy, and it feels buggy. When you die 'cos of that, well, it doesnt feel good. The game also has a sneaking" mechanic but
hoursPlayed: even in the very specific areas the game tells you to sneak around

reviewText:
Hydrophobia Prophecy isn't very good. But before I get into why, it's not completely awful. Considering it's a 2010 game, the graphics aren't bad, though not amazing. But it's the water physics that is this game's shining crown and glory. The water flows, pours and ripples naturally, not too clear and not too murky. When you open doors or break glass with varying water levels, the water flows from one area to another in waves and levels out. Dark Energy Digital have produced a very good water physics simulator in their HydroEngine. It's just a pity they didn't put as much effort into the game itself.

Why did I think this game was bad? Hydrophobia Prophecy aims to be a cover-based, stealth shooter, similar vein to Deus Ex but without the RPG elements. But the stealth elements are absolutely horrible as cover is the only real element that provides stealth. Because the stealth is so bad, the game becomes a generic, watered-down, cover-based shooter. You have 1 weapon with 5 different ammo (i.e. stun, single shot, auto-fire, remote detonation grenade and remote detonation shock grenade). Majority of encounters involved me shooting a guy enough times in the face before he killed me, waiting for my health to regenerate before moving onto the next guy.

Hydrophobia Prophecy is only worth having a go if you're interested in water physics in games. Otherwise the game is not very well done due to many flaws and bugs, only being about 3 hours long, poor design and poor mechanics. Dark Energy Digital went under after low sales of this game, which is unfortunately what happens when you produce a sub-par game. More unfortunately is their response to some negative reviews which can be read about in this article. Looking at the title image below, don't get fooled into thinking this is an action game where you use your magical water power to defeat the bad guys. The below image represents about 8.5% of the game, 6% of that being an awful, awkward, out of the blue boss fight.

For full review, visit:
http://icarusreviews.net/2014/10/03/hydrophobia-prophecy/

reviewText:
I do NOT recommend this game at all.
It was fine for the most part with not many bugs or anything.
I bought it on sale for just 0.99 euro but even that wont be low enough for some things in this game.

Cause i paid so little i didnt really mind the worst voice acting i have ever heard in a game.

But what i do mind is, you need to have V-sync on to make a specific jump to a ventilation system. Which is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t btw.

So no, even with a sale so low as 0.99 its not even worth the money.

reviewText:
A phenomenal game. Hydrophobia is a great game just with the water physics alone. Since the game revolves around that it easy to see why the gameplay is so good. Only complaint is the voice acting, which was rather poor and some specific instructions are not really explained in depth (until the end, which by then you have learned yourself). Also a lot of the good content is in the 3rd act (which is the finial act). The game is about 3 ~ 4 hours long and keeps you wanting to play it. Got it for $1.50 on midweek madness but it's only $5 normally. It's defiantly an underrated game. Would love to see a sequel.

-=Scoring=-
Gameplay 9/10
Story: 7/10
Creativity: 10/10 (Puzzles and stuff)
Uniqueness: 10/10 (Compared to other games)
Voice Acting: 5/10
Instructions: 7/10
Graphics 8/10 (The character models are average but the environment is great)

Overall about a 7.5/10 ~ 8/10

reviewText:
This is an interesting game. It's bad but in the good way. It isn't exactly average since it has that little something. But it isn't great either. The water control mechanics are neat and are fun to play with but are in my opinion underused. The story is just okay. It has an interesting world but the game is short. The graphics are average but water is delicious. The combat works but could use some improvement. My main problem with the game is that it's so short. It has some neat things in it but overall it's just an average game in the grand scheme of things. But it has that spark in it. Potential.

It is definitely nothing like you've ever played before but it is definitely worth a try for anyone even remotely interested in it.

----[Rating weighted based on the genre]----

Story: 3/5
Gameplay: 3/5
Challenge: 3/5
Discovery: 2.5/5
Replayability: 2/5
Aesthetics: 4/5
Visuals: 3.5/5
Atmosphere: 3/5
Music: 3/5

reviewText: This game I would call more of a Show piece. yes the game is serviceable but its main focus is showing off the engine. The weapon your given has unlimited ammo as long as you charge it as the first ammo type you get and personaly I dont have a need for the other 4 types of ammo  with targets down in 1 or 2 shots. The story is borderline a Tom Clancy game, Everything is peaceful, terrorist f*** things up and you need to fix it. Though all this the main character actually just feels like her role before all the issues hit. She isnt a sharp shooter and on normal she is very weak, she feels and plays like a regular person(besides her ability to hold her breath). Control wise this game is almost poor. Walking and swiming feel clunky and if the water isnt deep enough to swim over but still too deep to walk around you get some intresting bugs. This game has a stealth system but if the water gets too deep you make a moan and alert everyone near by. so far the game preformed decent until Act 3. Act 3 i had my mouse not respond 3 times in a row from an awkward bug i got while swiming and aiming. Overall the game looks nice, i just wish the combat and movement were a little less clunky so I could enjoy it. Now here is my biggest issue, at the time of writing this I am 2.2hrs in and the game is ALMOST OVER. luckly I got this on sale and didnt pay the $5 (I think this is still $15 or $20 on Xbox). So beware this game is EXTREAMLY SHORT and your in for about a 3hr story and a challage room(which I havent tried yet). But if your a Developer looking for an engie to handle water physics this is wonderful engie to use and should give this a shot.

reviewText: First off...it's a short game.  But it's an interesting game as well that has a bit of challenge too it.  The game has a variety of aspects to it: a bit of puzzle solving, a bit of shooting, a bit of creepy giggling dead girl (stay underwater for a while...you'll start to hear it), and of course...water physics (and of course no game with a female protagonist can avoid the all mighty overamped boob physics).  The water actually reacts in what seems like a realistic way including waves rolling through and walls of water flowing down hallways when doors are opened.  It's a great game if you're waiting for a new game to come out and need something to hold you over for several days.  Definitely worth a look.

reviewText:
Hydrophobia is a game that's got great gameplay and a decent amount of puzzle solving.  Sadly, though, it runs out of both pretty quickly.  A few more mechanics would have made it amazing, but it works with what it has.  This leads onto the game's major flaw: Hydrophobia is very short.  One can understand why this is, though, the game's levels explore its limited mechanics thoroughly, and more would have become repeditive.

The controls are a little bit awkward, it's clearly a console port and doesn't handle keyboard and mouse so well and has some weird accelleration.  It also ran my laptop very hot with the settings turned up to mid-high, but there wasn't much stuttering.  The game could probably be optimised somewhat.  If the developers had have spent more time polishing the game, it would have been quite excellent.

Overall, it's an entertaining little game.  Don't expect it to be taken away by it, but it's worth the few dollars you'll pay for it.

reviewText:
Lets get right down to it, is Hydrophobia: Prophecy bad?
Mechanically its ok, it works, the level design is solid, the water physics are frankly FANTASTIC, and overall the game functions pretty well. This game isn't a buggy mess or unfinished or a slog as I would have expected from the score.
Storywise however it could use some work, the dialogue could use some improvement especially in the introduction which has some very shakey voice acting. Combat is somewhat repeditive and an unituitive puzzle required me to shoot some dangling electrical cords right next to some explosive barrels instead of the barrels themselves.
Overall though after asking myself Would this be worth five bucks?" If you can ignore the introduction and don't really mind the plot then I would say this game is definately worth five bucks. Especially the first time you open a door from a flooded room and realize "holy crap this water isn't pre-animated.""
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Reminiscent of Tomb Raider, but in a much less primitive setting, Hydrophobia is technically impressive with a decent story to boot.  The fluid effects were awesome, although they sometimes brought my system to a crawl (it's rather dated).  The combat could get tedious, however, especially in the final boss, and the short playtime was disappointing... but for the price, I really have nothing to complain about.

reviewText: I own both the Xbox 360 and PC versions and running them side-by-side, the PC wins hands down. We wouldn't have Hydrophobia if it wasn't for the Xbox Live to give this indie crew a chance, but man... the story depth has really been cleaned up on the PC version and while I really enjoyed what was already there with the X360 version, the addition of the cutscenes is a blessing: it adds so much more to the tension. Graphics have been improved, sound has been improved (though I disagree with replacing the voice actor for Scoot: the original was much better!), controls are open for both gamepad and mouse/keyboard (both with their pros & cons) and the gameplay has benefit a lot from the extra time/funding the development team had for this version. Yes, it's still a work in progress (dev team has added an in-game feedback option for PC gamers), but dammit: you _must_ buy this game. Adventure/action lovers rejoice: Kate knocks the old Lara Croft right out of the park.

reviewText: Hydrophobia isn't a great game, but I've played worse. Playing style is similar to Tomb Raider, climbing around ledges to progress to the next area, with some basic 3rd person shooting vs enemies with poor AI. Weapon variety is poor but opportunities for environmental kills keep it fairly interesting. No huge Tomb Raider style puzzles though. The big draw of the game is the water physics. As the ship falls apart and water rushes in knocking you off your feet, there is a sense of panic, trying to get to safety before you drown. The story and voice acting are decent, but some plot threads are left unfinished. Feels like the first part of a larger game. Its unfortunate that the 3rd act goes all action, ending with a fairly frustrating boss fight. You get an interesting new ability very late which ties into the story, but don't really get chance to play around with it before the game ends. I finished in under 5 hours, but still value for money when on sale for £2.

reviewText:
Let's cut too the chase. Hydrophobia is a broken, janky game. Gameplay is finicky, the A.I. is poor, the story is confusing, the acting is inconsistent at best, the deaths are always cheap and its terribly short.

And in the end, I don't think I care about any of that.

Hydrophobia may be a foundementally flawed game, but it succeeds in delievering an experience you have never encountered in a game. It reminds me a lot of games like Free Radical's 'Second Sight' of EA's 'Mirror's Edge'; both are nowhere near perfect games. But because they offered up a gameplay experience or asethetic distinct from what we as gamers are typically given, makes them capivating and brilliant in their own right. So yes this games is a mess, but for the moments when everything comes together you can't help but find yourself completely taken into the world.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ok, this game has some AMAZING water effects.  Water flows very much like it would in real life.  It even has a tide that will pull you if you are caught in the current while water is flowing out of your room into the next.

Unfortunately, that's really all this title has to offer.  The acting makes B-movies sound like emmy award nominees.  And get this...2 hours!  That was the playtime to get through it.  I didn't even realize it was over till I started getting awards for Game completion".  So that is a terrible ending to a story when you are sitting there expecting to see the next level.

Luckily this game was cheap"

I recommend this game but only when its on sale not for full price.
The graphics are great and the water elements have been done very well, The option to use Mavi for navigation is really good and the character models arent bad either.
The bad points of this game have mostly been said already but the length of the game is too short, the water powers are few and unimaginative, most of the gun ammo types are useless, the enemies are idiots (seriously quite a lot of the time a few of them would just stare at the ceiling) and quite frankly the story escalated immensely quickly and didnt make a lot of sense, the location was also confusing was I on a boat, a city, a city that was a boat i couldnt say.
Even with all that i definitely think it is worth the 39p that it is going for at the moment I mean there are some games out there not even worth that much *cough* Ride to Hell *cough*

reviewText:
Hydrophobia? More like Hydroforgettable.

The game has an interesting concept but it all takes place in a location and a world that has little to no explanation about where you are and what's going on. It's clearly a sci-fi setting but we're not told anything about it. As such it's very hard to feel connected to the characters or plot since the lack of information about the setting leaves us very disconnected from what is happening.

It's not a terrible game but I'm definately glad I didn't pay more then 49 cents for it.

reviewText:
Eh, my experience with this game was bad, but probably because i went in with a bad mindstate. The beginning of the game was kinda rushed i guess, you wake up, grab tablet, go to work, then sh*t goes down, in 2 minutes, you're already in a sinking ship. I just felt that it was rushing you.

Now, oh GOSH the lag on this game. I have it lowest settings on an almost brand new laptop and it STILL lags.

From what looks like a selling point on the screenshots, you can control water, YES, but um... for the last 10 minutes of the game.... so nvm about that.

And as everyone is saying, final boss makes no sence to the story, but my thoughts on the final boss is F*CK THE FINAL BOSS, either my game glitched, or im misunderstanding something, but the enemies that the boss spawns are for some reason invincable for me, and i don't want to have to deal with it.

So overall, i'd say the game isn't bad, but it's not good either. It can be fun at times, but sometimes what you're supposed to do isn't exactly clear. It's fun to relieve the Titanic in a futuristic way, but this time with a bad final boss.

7.8/10 Too much water

reviewText: From all the screenshots, you'd think this would be a decent looking game. Well...it isn't. It REALLY isn't. I will admit that some of it looks alright but most of it looks like it's from a early ps3 game. The combat system just doesn't work. It feels messy and unfinished. You'd think this is early access but it isn't. Mind you, it was quite cheap when I got it but to be honest, that should have warned me as to the quality of the game. I'm just puting this out there to say Do not buy this game. Whatever little money it's asking for, it does not deserve. I'd understand the level of quality from this if it was a free mod for a game that someone made quickly in their spare time. The voice acting is mediocre at best. That few bits of money you still have in your steam wallet is better of staying in there than going into the pockets of this creator. Highly disapointed with this game

reviewText:
Graphics:

Feels unfinished. too often do i stare at things that only slightly feel out of place. It is however, not bad. Especially when it comes to the water! The water itself would get a solid 10/10, rest of the graphics 6/10, mainly due to the poor cutscene dialogue's (I CANNOT stand impropper lipsyncing).
(8/10 Total)

Audio:

Audio often weirded me out. I understand that the childs voice you hear underwater is PROBABLY from your trauma as you near suffocation underwater.... but hearing them the moment you jump into the water?
The voice used for Kate does not feel authentic either.
(4/10 total)

Story:

A horribly generic--- yet enjoyable storyline. The thing is however, that if you'd cut the whole story out, you would not be missing anything essential. The game feels seperated from the story (this may differ if you're a true collecter of collectables and learn more about the backstory). This does not matter however, seeing as the gameplay itself is of great quality.
(7/10 total)

Overal:

The game plays very well, it also has a GREAT feel to it. It does feel a bit unfinished however and i'm sure that with just a bit of polishing it would be perfect feel-wise.
Is it worth playing? Yes.
Is it worth buying? Maybe.
If it's on sale like it is now (-80%, 0,99 cents from 4,99) then yes, definately. The full price of 4,99 however, is barely worth it, seeing as the game is rather short (Completed in under 3 hours)

I do however, hope for a sequal to come out in which the audio/graphics are fully polished and the game lasts -+20 hours, which in my opinion, should be easily doable since some of the technique's you unlock at the end (no spoilers) will only be used for puzzling once or never.
If they manage to do all that, the game would be worth at least 29,99.

Final Score 7/10.

reviewText:
Well, I read alot of reviews saying that the game pretty much sucks.  It does not suck.  Despite the bad reviews I couldn't pass it up on sale for $0.49.  This game has some neat features in it.  The main issue is that there's really no need to use the neat features.  The game is very linear so there's never an opportunity to experiment using different abilities to clear an area.

What I liked: The use of fire, water, electricity, gravity was done pretty well.  The manipulation of world objects wasn't really as limited as most games.  If you see a box it can be moved, thrown, blown up, etc.  You can use bad guys and world objects equally to create havok.

The animations were pretty good.  The character struggled through hip deep water, sloshed through knee deep water, and gasped for air appropriately.  The character acts like it's running out of air when the breath meter gets to a certain point (swimming more erratically and paniced) Cover animations were decent and there were even fairly good proximity animations which alot of games tend to ignore. (Stand close to fire and the character shields her face.)

The story wasn't blockbuster but was fast paced. There were a lot of cutscenes too, which I'm a fan of.  I want to see things unfold, not just hit a button and proceed.  Makes it more cinematic.

What I didn't like: The boss fight was challenging but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  Also slightly confusing.

The level design was pretty weak.  There isn't really any sense to the layout of this place.

Two achievements are for 1. getting all the objects and 2. getting all the medals.  There's no indication of how many you missed.  As far as I know there's no list of medals that can be obtained either. You just play and try to get them?  Not cool.

You couldn't use abilities creatively enough.  You get a chance to open doors with hazards behind them as a learning part of the story, but then really never get to do it again.  Using the handheld tool you can see if there's water or fire or nothing behind a door but if it's off the path it's either locked or malfunctioning which means it might as well just be another wall.  You can shoot out glass doors, which is great fun, but pointless since there's nothing to do but then just move on content with the knowledge that you just shot a door.

The bad guys weren't intelligently placed.  They just kind of showed up in places that made no sense here and there to make you shoot things.  The bad guy placement was so bad that the majority of boss fight baddies can be left to the boss to take out.

All in all it's another linear shooter.  If it's linear, and a shooter, 99% of the time it'll also be generic.  It'd be worth it at $9.99.

The voice used for Kate does not feel authentic either.
(4/10 total)

Story:

A horribly generic--- yet enjoyable storyline. The thing is however, that if you'd cut the whole story out, you would not be missing anything essential. The game feels seperated from the story (this may differ if you're a true collecter of collectables and learn more about the backstory). This does not matter however, seeing as the gameplay itself is of great quality.
(7/10 total)

Overal:

The game plays very well, it also has a GREAT feel to it. It does feel a bit unfinished however and i'm sure that with just a bit of polishing it would be perfect feel-wise.
Is it worth playing? Yes.
Is it worth buying? Maybe.
If it's on sale like it is now (-80%, 0,99 cents from 4,99) then yes, definately. The full price of 4,99 however, is barely worth it, seeing as the game is rather short (Completed in under 3 hours)

I do however, hope for a sequal to come out in which the audio/graphics are fully polished and the game lasts -+20 hours, which in my opinion, should be easily doable since some of the technique's you unlock at the end (no spoilers) will only be used for puzzling once or never.
If they manage to do all that, the game would be worth at least 29,99.

Final Score 7/10.

reviewText:
Bought this while it was on sale for $3.00, let me tell you, THAT WAS A COMPLETE STEAL!  The water physics are amazingly good (better than you will see in any other game for 2011), and even though the plot is small and more or less easy to understand what happened during the events (not so much of the character back story), it's still a good game.  In a small nut shell:

Pros:
Good (but small) plot.
Water physics are amazing.
Has an okay cover and fire system.

Cons:
The camera is a little buggy, but you not to the point that it's unplayable.
Depth of Field is going to take a minute or 2 too get used to but again, not a major issue.
Expect to die a few times because you are up against AI with Shotguns and ARs while you only have a pistol (with different ammo types but you will mostly be using stun like ammo.) and your health is a joke.

I know there are more cons then Pros, but its really a good game.

reviewText: An interesting game with really amazing water physics, but it's unfortunately lacking in some other aspects. But for the low price it went down to, it's a bargain. As I'm writing this, it's just 1,24€ here (on -75% daily deal). The reason to get it is the fantastic water physics implemented that I haven't seen done so well in any other game. You'll enjoy the really natural look of the water filling the sinking ship you're in. It rises, it has currents, waves, very naturally flows out of flooded rooms as you open the door, releasing the water... The surface ripples according to all water movement and reflects the light beautifully. However... this game is very short. And the action aspects (shooting, that is) aren't done so well. The weapons are kinda lame and it generally feels pretty static compared to typical action games. I consider this game a demonstration of the impressive water engine and it's a shame they didn't put as much work on other things. But try it out!

reviewText: This game was another great value. Where this game stands out is the water is a character of it's own. You have to fight against water and use water to your advantage. There were many flaws in the game (blow up power, but the ship still has power; water is electrified, but only effects you if you are close; etc) that could have been better planned out. There are also a few glitches still, for example the audio from your character is not in the same spacial location as your current location. I also liked this game because it focused on story and not on thousands of collectibles and achievements. I recommend this to anyone who is willing to forgive some flaws for an inexpensive day of gaming.

reviewText:
Not the greatest game ever, the entire game feels very clunky, difficult to tell where people are shooting at you from, where the heck you’re going, and walking around is difficult, and swimming can be downright impossible. These serve to make the game infuriating, as you bumble your way around a sinking ship; being shot at by everybody you meet. What’s worse is the game’s supposedly ‘unique’ water powers don’t show up until basically the end of the game, and they are SUPER lame. All you can do is pick up stuff and toss it around using giant pillars of water. And as soon as you get these powers the game is basically over after a very annoying boss battle.

Honestly, the game sucks. It’s basically a half-baked piece of crap. The game has a very interesting premise, and with more work could have been a good game. Sadly the game falls very short of anything close to fun, and can only be described as an annoying experience that you keep waiting to get better, when you finally expect it to get good, the game ends.

My recommendation is to not get this game, if for some god awful reason you want this game get it while on sale.

reviewText:
This game is obviously designed for console users and not PC players, like myself, because of the controls and 360 environment.

Very interesting story and exciting adrenaline inducer.

I prefer PC because 360 spins give me motion sickness and I've only played one 360 game all the way through because of this issue.  Headaches and nausea is not my idea of fun.

The environment is also very disorienting and activities that would seem intuitive and obvious in real life are not always apparent on a computer screen.

I recommend this game for its non violent nature and realistic story line.

Picked this up for 39p on a steam sale, knowing it would be a glorified tech demo. I didn't mind for that price, just wanted to see the water physics and play around with them.

Unfortunately a combination of the dreadful voice acting and broken jumping mechanics led me to abandon my quest after half a dozen failed attempts at the first jumping puzzle. On the plus side, made me very nostalgic about falling to my death in the Tomb Raider series.

reviewText:
Not the greatest game ever, the entire game feels very clunky, difficult to tell where people are shooting at you from, where the heck you’re going, and walking around is difficult, and swimming can be downright impossible. These serve to make the game infuriating, as you bumble your way around a sinking ship; being shot at by everybody you meet. What’s worse is the game’s supposedly ‘unique’ water powers don’t show up until basically the end of the game, and they are SUPER lame. All you can do is pick up stuff and toss it around using giant pillars of water. And as soon as you get these powers the game is basically over after a very annoying boss battle.

Honestly, the game sucks. It’s basically a half-baked piece of crap. The game has a very interesting premise, and with more work could have been a good game. Sadly the game falls very short of anything close to fun, and can only be described as an annoying experience that you keep waiting to get better, when you finally expect it to get good, the game ends.

My recommendation is to not get this game, if for some god awful reason you want this game get it while on sale.

reviewText: This game was another great value. Where this game stands out is the water is a character of it's own. You have to fight against water and use water to your advantage. There were many flaws in the game (blow up power, but the ship still has power; water is electrified, but only effects you if you are close; etc) that could have been better planned out. There are also a few glitches still, for example the audio from your character is not in the same spacial location as your current location. I also liked this game because it focused on story and not on thousands of collectibles and achievements. I recommend this to anyone who is willing to forgive some flaws for an inexpensive day of gaming.

reviewText:
The game despite being short and quite repetative is worth playing. Why?
First let me tell you what is wrong with the game (there is quite a lot!)

Cons:
-Character handles poorly, especially in 3 deminsional environments.
-Story lacking explaination and execution.
-Character develpoment: Non Existant.
-Missions very repetative.
-Platforming not imaginative (in most cases).
-Enemies are not very difficult to defeat.
-Voice acting is quite bad.
-Lip syncing is awful.
-Repeated models (for example in one scene two identical men, are lined up and exacuted)
...

Now you are probably thinking, 'What is the point of playing this game then?'

The most standout feature of this game is the level of exploration. At times the game reminds me of the film Posidon Adventure. The game is very good at making the player second guess themselves, and ask questions. Now while this level of exploration is not consistant, for the parts that it is in makes this game highly enjoyable.

This game for me personally is a showcase (eventhough to my knowlege it is not), a showcase of the possibilities for games made by larger companies. For example if bioshock or bioshock 2 implmeted the water system that this game uses it could have been probably one of the best games of the decade (it still is very good).

reviewText:
Hydrophobia, a cross between adventure and third person shooter. The game starts on a giant ship which houses tonnes of people. You play as a mechanical engineer who is trying to foil the terorist attack on the vessel.

The game is relatively cheap at $5 (I got it for about $1 at sale :D). The main selling point of the game is the water mechanics. You can control the flow of water to open paths and even defeat enemies. The water graphics are really good (it looks and moves fluidly).

Now for the bad points. Although the water graphics are good, other models (ie. characters, environment) seem somewhat bland. The voice acting isn't that great either, nor is the story unfortunately. The biggest problem I had with the game were lag spikes. Alot of lag spikes. Although it's a single player only game, it lagged and even freezes (for a few minutes at a time) on me in several areas even after lowering all the graphical settings to bottom. I play games like retribution and crysis  fine with minimum lag, but this game struggles to run for some reason. The third person shooting is also clunky as the movement controls aren't great.


Overall, the game does try to be unique with the water mechanics, but it doesn't make up the the under par graphics, story, controls and bugs. I haven't finished it (due to the bugs), but after spending 2 hours in it I'm not really compelled to play it. Save your money people.

reviewText: The game looks beautiful and the water physics are very well done. The platforming and puzzles are not too confusing and feel rewarding. However the story was rather short, only 4 hours or so and it leaves a lot left for the player to think about as the ending is confusing and felt rather rushed. The combat works pretty well, with cover mechanics and different ammo types, along with the power to control water which is great fun. The combat can feel rather awkward and clunky sometimes as the enemy AI is usually stupid. The guns didnt really sounds like guns either, more like someone making the sound effects with their mouth, but overall the combat was pretty fun.\n\nIn conclusion I think Hydrophobia is a good game for what it's worth (5 bucks, currently 99 cents as I write this review), and looks very very nice. However A sequel or an expansion would be great to fill up those plot holes. I do reccomend this game if you want some thing short, fun, cheap and well designed.

reviewText: Unique. Certainly not the longest game I've ever played nor the most in depth story, but unique to be sure. A nice assortment of weapon ammo with various ways to dispatch enemies, whether that be through direct damage, explosion, fire, or drowning.  Nifty mapping system with a neat pda-style way of locating objectives.  There is constantly the sensation of feeling like you're about to drown, especially since about 50% of the game takes place underwater.  All in all a pretty good game.  I'm glad I played it, enjoyable enough to experience the water physics alone.  I give it a solid B".  Not B-

reviewText:
Interesting take on the 'Survival' genre.  Decent value.

Plot seems nice while story is a little weak.  You're a super-smart-super-brave systems engineer that just happens to be a totally-in-shape rock climber in her spare time and also, judging by the award on her kitchen table in the beginning (from 7th grade?!), an accomplished swimmer and combat shows her to be a crack shot with a pistol as well.

Wish they played up the 'Hydrophobia' aspect of the game as well as it seems the main character suffers from it, and it is the namesake of the game.  She does verbally freak out when an area floods, but other than that stays calm as water rapidly floods and while she swims past dead bodies and such.

The whole reason I got this game tho was the amazing water physics, and to me, they more than make up for the shortcomings of the game.  The way the water flows, pushes against your character, floods through doorways as they open, etc are all fantastic and add an extra dimension to gameplay.

reviewText: Hydrophobia: Prophecy has gotten a lot of negative press, both for the quality of the game and for the outlandish PR department. Although tempting, it's important to not attribute negative qualities of people to the work they create.\nThat being said, Hydrophobia isn't a very good game. At it's best it oddly reminds me of Beyond Good and Evil. At it's very worst it redefines a new low. The controls are terri-bad (I've never experienced worse controls then the underwater sections.) The optomization is awful, there are constant FPS drops and  an overall low performance. While the graphics are nice, the animations are horrendous. That is, minus the water physics: hands down the best water effects I've ever seen. The story is interesting, if not presented very awkwardly. It's obvious that effort was put into it. The game isn't very long; it took me a little under three hours to complete, not stopping to explore.

reviewText: Even at $3 this game is overpriced. It looks, feels and sounds like some interns made it and voice acted it. The gameplay is like a poor man's Assassins Creed, only with terrible controls and plot, with a linear path. They try and add a sense of urgency by adding timed missions, all of which can be completed with over half of the time left on the clock. Be weary of a game which goes on sale for 75% off this close to the launch date. Also, the main protagonist is an annoying girl who does nothing but complain about her situation the entire time. So if you want to play a game that complains that you're playing it, while simultaniously being no fun to begin with, then buy this game. If you aren't into playing crap for the sake of playing crap, then save the $3 and buy a sandwhich.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game had quite a bit of potential going for it, all of which falls flat on its face by the end. The controls are clunky fit awkwardly with the sudden changes in camera behavior, especially when entering water. Enemies will appear seemingly at random around you, including behind you and from locations you were just in. Graphical glitches crop up frequently, including ones where the floor and wall textures fail to load. The design flaws are numerous, including one noteable example of being knocked to my death in a forced animation by a scripted sequence where terrain collapses as the character is climbing up some debris.

The level design is poor, not utilizing any external environments at all which could have aided in both the game's quality and length  as it's set on a giant boat yet at no point do you go outside and are instead relgated to wandering a series of corridors within the ship's bowels. Also, this game is very short, only a few hours of play at best.

Buy only under $5.

reviewText:
So, this game is very short, and the combat is sub-par, but it is still a good game to grab for the price.

It is a very cool game, the water physics is very fun to mess around in, and it is very good. The combat could use some improvement, but overall it is alright. The main problem is the climbing. If you do not run Vsync, you are going to have a very bad time. If you don't believe me, try to compare. You have to run it with it, it makes the combat so smoother, and you cannot complete the game without it, so make sure to enable it. The other lacking part is the story. Bland, boring, and most of all, it doesn't have an ending. It has no closure, and it kinda just rolls to the credits, which is a shame, because it seems like a cool world. You are on a giant ship, and it starts to flood from a terrorist attack. That is pretty much all they say. You don't know why, you don't know the characters, you only really learn your name from the character talking to herself (Which I still don't know what it is.) But still, if you like Tomb Raider, you will probably enjoy this game.

6.75/10

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Overall: 7/10
Graphics: 8/10
Gameplay: 7/10
Story: 6/10

I know this game gets a bad rap for being short and having a lacking story, but I found it easy to get into the story and keep up.  It's something you have to pay attention to.  I didn't find the story really all that boring, I'm just disappointed that you don't get your powers until late in the game when they're a bit irrelevant.  (I'm so used to shooting my guns that I don't know if I'll use the powers much.)

I also liked that the main focus, water, had life to it.  It wasn't just something that was everywhere and utterly useless, you could actually use it to progress in the game.  Need to go up one level but no stairs/ladder/etc?  Can't go through a door because there is a fire right in front of it?   Shoot a wall and ride the flood.   Need to get to the next part of the story and don't feel like killing your way through a group of 10 guys?  You guessed it, OPEN THE FLOOD GATES AND SHOOT DOWN SOME POWER LINES.

Too many indie developers go for generic, popular themes such as the ever popular Zombie shooter or some post-apocalyptic world that has little to no back story as to how things happened (or it takes forever to know the full story).  It's refreshing that they did their own spin on a futuristic dying Earth where the problem was over-population and not some catastrophic apocolyptic event.

For $5($0.49 during steam sales), this game gives you your money's worth and 8 times out of 10 you'll enjoy playing this for a few hours.  I got this through a Humble Bundle, so I didn't pay more than $0.10 for it, therefore take what I say with a grain of salt.

reviewText: Review #43...Hydrophobia.  Lame fact: this is the irrational fear of water, usually as a result of a rabies infected animal bite.  Why is this relevant?  Because the game has no bite.  Neat and interesting ideas yes, a reason to keep playing it no.  Some games i feel compelled to complete it to the point of 100% as far as achievements go (not because i consider the achievements the defining element, but because the game was that enjoyable).   At this point, the graphics are dated, and some would even consider the physics outdated.  It comes off as an experiement, or proof of concept.  Maybe if the game had been longer, or a little more polished it wouldn't come off that way.  As it is, it's dime store knockoff of Tomb Raider and Uncharted.\n\nIt is a decent game...if you can get it in a bundle.  Otherwise it has to be a no.

reviewText:
This might be the best game you've never heard of. Take the climbing and environmental puzzles from Tomb Raider, Shooting / sneaking / wall hugging from Riddik and the swimming fom Mario 64. ... if Mario 64 had underwater combat, explosions and dynamic water modelling

reviewText: Although my feelings for this game are mixed, I'm going to give it a recommendation. It's not necesarily a bad game (at least if you have a responsive keyboard and mouse--something I did not have a majority of the game), but the entire story feels rushed. The ending is just kind of there and I found myself questioning what even happened to every main character--except Mila. The voice acting and music is mediocre, but they do their jobs fine. The highlight of the game would have to be the visuals--especially the water. The game isn't very difficult (I played on hard mode and only took more than an hour and a half  because my keyboard was running low on batteries), but the difficulty could be both a good or bad aspect depending on the player. Overall, the game isn't great but considering it's $4.99 and goes on sale for $0.49, it's a solid buy. In short, I give Hydrophobia a solid 75/100 and a buy it if you have the extra change.

reviewText:
Hydrophobia is a game that didn't get the best reviews, especially before it was pached. Personally I still like the game a lot and enjoy playing it. I think that this can be a very good and enjoyable game if you dont expect this it to be something its not and like this kind of games in general.

This is not a AAA game with all the aspects being of top quality. It doesn't have the worlds best story-line or a lot of new and innovative gameplay elements. This is the kind of game that you play for fun or to relax after a hard day. If you like 3D adventure games with a little action here and there, like I do, this could be the game you are looking for. For the most part, this is really just an simple modern adventure-game with fun and quite repetive gameplay. It's for you to decide if that is a good thing or not. Most of the gameplay is jumping, running and swimming around and solving some, for the most part very simple puzzles. In the later parts of the game there is also some shooting and similar action. One thing I liked so much about this game is that it is still relatively low on action, witch makes it one of the kind of games that there are still not too much around these days for those who like 3D-adventure games, but not a lot of action/violence.

Another thing that separates this from the masses is the gender-roles seen in this game. While most of the games we see have protagonists that are white, young, macho straight men with big muscles this game brings a protagonist that seems  new and refreshing being more of a masculine woman. Of course, there's absolutely nothing wrong with macho men but for those gamers that don't identify with that kind of gender expression or simply like change this could also be seen as a good thing about this game.

Probably the best and most innovative thing about this game is still the water and the effects associated to it. The water is really fun to play with and I really enjoyed wathing it wave from room to room. The behavior of the water is more realistic than I have seen in any other game up to this day. The water, fire and electricity really make the athmosphere of the game and are beautifull to look at.

It is worth noting that these are just my subjective experiences and views of the game and I also have not finished the game entirely yet. This is also the first game review that I have ever written! :)

For the price I bought it (0,49 euro) and being an indie game I would say Hydrophobia is a really fun experience and even has a few new elements that I enjoyed.

reviewText: Guys, I found rock bottom, and it's called Hydrophobia: Prophecy. Minimal explanations, no clear resolutions, a combat system that's almost as clunky as the one in Ride to Hell: Retribution, and no clear explanations for the opening or endings. Oh, and did I mention there's only like four hours of gameplay, tops? However, the game's one saving grace is that the water physics and graphics are phenomenal. I mean, they made an engine just for the water graphics and physics, and it acts like real water. Damn, that is some FINE water. 10/10 would tap this water (sorry not sorry). Is this game really just a less sucky Water Temple? Is hydrokinesis contagious? Is Hydrophobia actually an advertisement for Aquafina? I'm going to go with yes, no, and I can't think of any other justification for this game (another yes). Overall, I give this stagnating, glorified aquarium a 4.10. Now if you'll excuse me, I need to go buy some Aquafina.

reviewText:
Want to play with water?
If you are water person, this is a game for you.

There is really a lot of water in it.
Swimming.
Flooding corridors and rooms.
Swimming fast.
Walking in water.
Shooting is so - so.
Your operator's jokes are so bad they're good.
There is some cover mechanics.
Few kinds of ammo for your gun.
Hacking minigame which does not suck or frustrate much.

A lot of environmental damage sources, think barrels, electric panels you can blow up to electrocute people.
Level design and graphics are quite nice.
Production value is ok.
It's over in 5 hours, but a lot cheaper than a movie ticket.

I do recommend, but don't expect insane replayability value.
This is a linear game that will allow you to play with water :>

reviewText:
So I just finished playing Hydrophobia. Here's some thoughts.
Flow and mood are excellent. The scenes were well-directed.
Puzzle-solving was... it would have been good but there was a lot of hand-holding; you basically follow a carrot on a stick through the whole game, which feels largely on rails.
They sold the game based on the idea that you'd have cool hydrokinesis powers, but you only have them for the last 15% of the game if that.
The hydrokinesis is cludgy to control and not all that useful. You can't use it from cover and it's less powerful as a weapon than the sonic stun bullets you use for the other 85% of the game.
You also get real bullets but they suck so I never really used them. The sonic rounds have more stopping power and accuracy so why would I use semiauto or fullauto?
There's some stealth for about 5 minutes but you end up shooting everyone in the face anyway.
After the game ends you unlock a challenge room" but I don't care.



---SPOILERS BELOW---
There is one boss fight

reviewText:
Hydrophobia: Prophecy. What I think of it.
Warning! Long review is long. You have been warned.

-Default Gameplay Mechanics: 7/10
The default buttons are a bit annoying, but they can be remapped. Way points are misleading and don't help when you're stuck.There are things you have to look at very closely to be able to progress. The cover system sometimes doesn't wanna work so the character doesn't go for cover. Diving underwater sometimes happened randomly when I didn't want to dive. Health regen system, which is common in many games, makes an appearance in this one. The boss sometimes glitched out (see Boss Difficulty below).

-Resolution: 10/10
Many resolutions to pick from. I was able to play it with my laptop connected to my big screen TV via HDMI on full screen.

-Maximum Overall Graphics: 10/10
Hands down, the best water graphics I've ever seen. Ending cutscene had the worst graphics in the entire game. Water graphics could easily make up for it.
NOTE: The game is all about the water.

-Storyline: 6/10 (SPOILERS)
A metropolis floating on water is attacked by a terrorist group known as Neo Malthusians. You, the character, are trapped and the area you are in is flooding. With the guidance from your buddy working the security cameras, you find a way to **escape**.
It was good for the first 2 acts then suddenly became wtf on the second half of act 3. And it only has 3 acts. The game can be beaten in less than 4 hours if you know what to do. My first playthrough was 4 hours. And that's not beating it 100%.
**It has a horrible ending with no resolution of any kind whatsoever. After beating the boss practically nothing happens**

-Normal Enemy Difficulty on Easy: 9/10
The enemies were pretty easy. They did get some cheap hits every now and then. It's hard to tell if an enemy is dead or down from a certain distance.

-Boss Difficulty: 6/10
The last and only boss is ludicrously powerful. A woman (who can be assumed as the terrorist leader) takes control of a machine that has a mini-gun, rocket-type projectiles, and grenade launcher. It sometimes glitched out to the point where I had to restart the battle almost 10 times. When it tossed out bombs, it covered a large portion of the room and they're very hard to see so I didn't know where was considered safe. Getting cornered for one second is almost guaranteed death unless you're lucky to survive.

Price: $4.99
A bit high price for a short game. I got it when it was on special for $0.49, so I don't really regret it.

-Overall: 6.5/10 - Pretty much the MetaScore (for once I agree with it)
I liked the game. The majority of the storyline is good and it's not too long to beat. But, it had some painfully obvious problems (everything mentioned above). If the developer/publisher company didn't go bankrupt a couple of years ago, they could have made this game so much better.
I'd recommend it, but honestly, you'd be better off buying it on sale for $0.49 than the regular $5 price.

reviewText: Hydrophobia: Prophecy is an interesting concept that fails too deliver on serveral fronts. The story revolves around Kate Wilson a security agent on a massive ship named Queen of the World". The homeworld (presumably Earth) lacks resources too sustain human populations; a lucky few live in luxury on the Queen of the World out in the ocean. The cruiser is attacked by a terrorist oragnization known as the Malthusians
date: a not so clever reference too economist Thomas Malthus. It is up to Kate and what is left of the security forces too navigate and salvage the sinking ship.\nWhere Hydrophobia fails is in exectution. The game is near impossible too play with a keyboard and is very difficult too use a controller as well. The puzzles are relatively easy
recommended: as the game itself always points you in the right direction. The voice acting is absolutely atrocious. The voice actors have no emotion in reading a poor script
hoursPlayed: which eventually grates on the players ears. Nobody talks like they do in Hydrophobia
voteText: in some circumstances it was humorous

The more I found myself playing the game the more I wanted too turn it off. The pretty water and occasional shootouts do not salvage this game. I can only recommend purchasing this game if it is on sale with a huge discount. Even then you are not missing out.\n\n-Alex"

reviewText:
I honestly do not understand the reasons for such low scores on this game.

For the time period, this was pretty neat graphically, and I am always happy to check out engine attempts.

The water physics are really well done here, and even if the game feels a bit hollow at the core, it playes decent and I am having fun.

Considering how cheap this gets on sale, WTH is wrong with people wanting to complain so much?

What is this game like?  Kind of like a level based Resident Evil-ish stirred in with a bit of Budget Raideresque climbing and jumping.

What do you get for your dollar or so on sale?  You get an average title that attempted to display some new ideas in an engine, a decent bit of playtime, and a story that isn't as bad as a good majority of games like it.

Would I suggest a Buy?  He11 yeah I would!

This is not the action game of the year, but it is a complete and working title that does exactly as I expected.
If you want something that is not super pricey, and yet can still return on your dollar (literally less than a pouch of crisps).

Buy it on sale if budget, or engine concept" games interest you.

Do not buy this if you want a $30+ polished supergame."

reviewText:
Hydrophobia: Prophecy....it's not terrible.

Pros:

-Water graphics and physics are great in this game.

- It frequently goes on sale. (I got the game for 49 cents or something like that.)

Cons:

-Controls. It seems like the game wants to be played on a controller rather than M/KB.

-Gameplay seems uneven. It seems like the devs put a huge emphasis on the first act/ act and a half of the game but then just gave up near the end. I would have liked to have mini-bosses for each act.

-Story is nothing to write home about. Terrorists being terrorists and what not. AND SO MANY UNANSWERED QUESTIONS!

Conclusion:

I'm going to recommend this game despite it's flaws with the stipulation that you buy it on sale. The game is short. I beat the game in about 5 hours. It's not a great game but it's not terrible and it would at least be something to keep you busy for 5 hours.

reviewText: The game looks beautiful and the water physics are very well done. The platforming and puzzles are not too confusing and feel rewarding. However the story was rather short, only 4 hours or so and it leaves a lot left for the player to think about as the ending is confusing and felt rather rushed. The combat works pretty well, with cover mechanics and different ammo types, along with the power to control water which is great fun. The combat can feel rather awkward and clunky sometimes as the enemy AI is usually stupid. The guns didnt really sounds like guns either, more like someone making the sound effects with their mouth, but overall the combat was pretty fun.\n\nIn conclusion I think Hydrophobia is a good game for what it's worth (5 bucks, currently 99 cents as I write this review), and looks very very nice. However A sequel or an expansion would be great to fill up those plot holes. I do reccomend this game if you want some thing short, fun, cheap and well designed.
