reviewText: An excellent concept, executed near perfectly. It's obvious that there was a $10 price tag in mind, but the game does such a good job of immersing you, that you quickly forget. The water physics in this game far exceed anything else on the market, and the company makes full use of the engine by giving you just about every scenario possible. Unfortunately, it's a short game and rather lacking in the story department. I was expecting it to amount to something more spectacular (like seeing the actual exterior of the ship) rather than the same old rooms for six hours, but no. Instead you're left trying to outrun rapidly flooding hallways all while gunning down some rather extreme liberators, as the world's population is far beyond sustainable. Our heroine, Kate, then develops a rather strange, but convenient ability. Then for no apparent reason, she must fight a giant flying robot. A strange way to end it, but overall an entertaining experience definitely worth $10. 8 / 10

reviewText:
Hydrophobia's got novel gameplay and setting, and some seriously impressive water (I spent a lot of time staring at it through the wireframe scanner... the tech is beautiful). Water (and fear of water) are used very well to implement some unique and fun gameplay. Cool hacking and a smooth introduction of new gameplay throughout the game keep it interesting, and the story is promising, as well.

Unfortunately this game's clearly rushed near the end, with a large amount of story elements and gameplay mechanics presented to the player all at once. This was originally going to be an episodic release and never saw any sequels. The game still reaches an ending that's fairly satisfying, despite that.

The survival mode you unlock by winning at least serves as a fun way to explore the cool new moves they introduce at the end.

reviewText:
First Impression Review of Hydrophobia: Prophecy

The first things I noticed when I  turned on this game were that the graphics were beautiful, the voice acting was impressive and my computer would never be able to run it properly in a million years.  After a few restarts and a lot of tweaking of settings I managed to get Hydrophobia to run by sacrificing the graphics and pretty much everything else.

When the game starts, it throws you immediately into the story. Hydrophobia: Prophecy is set on a city sized boat called Queen Of The World, sometime during the mid 21st century. Queen Of The World is  having some sort of anniversary celebration (whether anniversary of it’s founding or anniversary of completing a trip around the world I’m not sure) and out of the blue, the main communications server goes offline. Kate Wilson, a systems engineer, goes to investigate. With communications down a terrorist organization called the Malthusians hack the main security computer and a series of explosions rip holes into the hull.

Overall, the game seems quite well made with only a few minor bugs (some of the items float randomly when picked up rather than staying in your hand) and a dynamic liquid system that I haven’t seen anywhere else. However, one thing I can criticize is that the level design is quite confusing, often leading me to walk off in the wrong direction with little reward for doing so.

As a summary, Hydrophobia: Prophecy is a promising title and from what I’ve seen in my 77 minutes in-game it is well worth its $5.00 price tag, despite its few issues.

reviewText:
I honestly do not understand the reasons for such low scores on this game.

For the time period, this was pretty neat graphically, and I am always happy to check out engine attempts.

The water physics are really well done here, and even if the game feels a bit hollow at the core, it playes decent and I am having fun.

Considering how cheap this gets on sale, WTH is wrong with people wanting to complain so much?

What is this game like?  Kind of like a level based Resident Evil-ish stirred in with a bit of Budget Raideresque climbing and jumping.

What do you get for your dollar or so on sale?  You get an average title that attempted to display some new ideas in an engine, a decent bit of playtime, and a story that isn't as bad as a good majority of games like it.

Would I suggest a Buy?  He11 yeah I would!

This is not the action game of the year, but it is a complete and working title that does exactly as I expected.
If you want something that is not super pricey, and yet can still return on your dollar (literally less than a pouch of crisps).

Buy it on sale if budget, or engine concept" games interest you.

Do not buy this if you want a $30+ polished supergame."

reviewText:
Hydrophobia: Prophecy....it's not terrible.

Pros:

-Water graphics and physics are great in this game.

- It frequently goes on sale. (I got the game for 49 cents or something like that.)

Cons:

-Controls. It seems like the game wants to be played on a controller rather than M/KB.

-Gameplay seems uneven. It seems like the devs put a huge emphasis on the first act/ act and a half of the game but then just gave up near the end. I would have liked to have mini-bosses for each act.

-Story is nothing to write home about. Terrorists being terrorists and what not. AND SO MANY UNANSWERED QUESTIONS!

Conclusion:

I'm going to recommend this game despite it's flaws with the stipulation that you buy it on sale. The game is short. I beat the game in about 5 hours. It's not a great game but it's not terrible and it would at least be something to keep you busy for 5 hours.

reviewText:
So, this game is very short, and the combat is sub-par, but it is still a good game to grab for the price.

It is a very cool game, the water physics is very fun to mess around in, and it is very good. The combat could use some improvement, but overall it is alright. The main problem is the climbing. If you do not run Vsync, you are going to have a very bad time. If you don't believe me, try to compare. You have to run it with it, it makes the combat so smoother, and you cannot complete the game without it, so make sure to enable it. The other lacking part is the story. Bland, boring, and most of all, it doesn't have an ending. It has no closure, and it kinda just rolls to the credits, which is a shame, because it seems like a cool world. You are on a giant ship, and it starts to flood from a terrorist attack. That is pretty much all they say. You don't know why, you don't know the characters, you only really learn your name from the character talking to herself (Which I still don't know what it is.) But still, if you like Tomb Raider, you will probably enjoy this game.

6.75/10

reviewText:
Overall: 7/10
Graphics: 8/10
Gameplay: 7/10
Story: 6/10

I know this game gets a bad rap for being short and having a lacking story, but I found it easy to get into the story and keep up.  It's something you have to pay attention to.  I didn't find the story really all that boring, I'm just disappointed that you don't get your powers until late in the game when they're a bit irrelevant.  (I'm so used to shooting my guns that I don't know if I'll use the powers much.)

I also liked that the main focus, water, had life to it.  It wasn't just something that was everywhere and utterly useless, you could actually use it to progress in the game.  Need to go up one level but no stairs/ladder/etc?  Can't go through a door because there is a fire right in front of it?   Shoot a wall and ride the flood.   Need to get to the next part of the story and don't feel like killing your way through a group of 10 guys?  You guessed it, OPEN THE FLOOD GATES AND SHOOT DOWN SOME POWER LINES.

Too many indie developers go for generic, popular themes such as the ever popular Zombie shooter or some post-apocalyptic world that has little to no back story as to how things happened (or it takes forever to know the full story).  It's refreshing that they did their own spin on a futuristic dying Earth where the problem was over-population and not some catastrophic apocolyptic event.

For $5($0.49 during steam sales), this game gives you your money's worth and 8 times out of 10 you'll enjoy playing this for a few hours.  I got this through a Humble Bundle, so I didn't pay more than $0.10 for it, therefore take what I say with a grain of salt.

reviewText: Guys, I found rock bottom, and it's called Hydrophobia: Prophecy. Minimal explanations, no clear resolutions, a combat system that's almost as clunky as the one in Ride to Hell: Retribution, and no clear explanations for the opening or endings. Oh, and did I mention there's only like four hours of gameplay, tops? However, the game's one saving grace is that the water physics and graphics are phenomenal. I mean, they made an engine just for the water graphics and physics, and it acts like real water. Damn, that is some FINE water. 10/10 would tap this water (sorry not sorry). Is this game really just a less sucky Water Temple? Is hydrokinesis contagious? Is Hydrophobia actually an advertisement for Aquafina? I'm going to go with yes, no, and I can't think of any other justification for this game (another yes). Overall, I give this stagnating, glorified aquarium a 4.10. Now if you'll excuse me, I need to go buy some Aquafina.

It only lasted 6 hours with a simple story with bland gameplay.

While the graphics weren't too bad, the enemies all look almost the same with no variations and combat consists mostly of hiding in cover and shooting. While the sound effects are servicable, the music is forgettable.

The main selling point is the ability to control water. While the water physics effects are interesting to look at, it has been seen in dozens of games before. Furthermore you get this skill much too late in the game for it to be of any use.

The only interesting feature was the use of an ingame PDA which allowed the character to have an augmented reality view to scan for objects and clues. This was unfortunately under-utilized, and didn't improve the overall boring feel of the game.

Overall Rating: 4.5 / 10
Not worth to buy even if on sale, unless you have absolutely nothing to play.

reviewText:
Right, so I was scrolling up and down on my enormous steam library list, looking for something to play, and I ended up picking random things on my list and installing them, this was one of the things.

Hydrophobia: Prophecy is very short, the game time you see I have played is the time it took me completing this title, and I have no intentions to return to this title anytime soon.
As it starts up my first impressions was that it looked pretty good, although considering it came out in 2010, it is certainly not the best looking title of its time. The most interesting thing in the visual side, is the water, wich looks great and wich is also simulated very nicely, more on that later. The game starts out in the protagonists apartment, showcasing a futuristic but messy home, of an engineer living on some boat-a-majig. There is snippets of lore scattered around the world, but I found it to be largely uniteresting, and uninspired. It seems as if it is set in the futuristic setting everybody and thier mom uses, with white walls and sharp edges. Also the simple colouring, as you might see in titles such as Mirror's edge, is used here. Oh Mirror's Edge, released in 2008; much supirior in terms of visuals.

reviewText:
I like the look and setting of the game, and up to a point I can kinda forgive the not quite enthralling gameplay. As others have said, its kinda Tomb Raider-y, but the adventure elements are kinda sparse it feels like, so its a lot of just shooting and going from place to place.

The powers you get are pretty good, and I think well implemented, but a lot of the time there's not much call to use them, and when it makes/requires you use them its kinda annoying (it works better as 'hey you have these powers, think of cool ways to use them', rather than simply 'use power a to accomplish thing b')  Didn't like the boss fights at all, not sure I was at the final boss when I quit, but it was a rather annoying fight (I never really cared for boss fights which use infinitely spawning goons as a challenge.)

Story/setting was good, characters were good, voice acting was kinda ok (though I wouldn't say it was great), gameplay was meh. I'd probably give it a 3/5, there's entertainment to be had, but not derived from the gameplay.

(*btw most of my time on record in the game is just because I left it running for a while after changing input on my tv)

reviewText:
So I just finished playing Hydrophobia. Here's some thoughts.
Flow and mood are excellent. The scenes were well-directed.
Puzzle-solving was... it would have been good but there was a lot of hand-holding; you basically follow a carrot on a stick through the whole game, which feels largely on rails.
They sold the game based on the idea that you'd have cool hydrokinesis powers, but you only have them for the last 15% of the game if that.
The hydrokinesis is cludgy to control and not all that useful. You can't use it from cover and it's less powerful as a weapon than the sonic stun bullets you use for the other 85% of the game.
You also get real bullets but they suck so I never really used them. The sonic rounds have more stopping power and accuracy so why would I use semiauto or fullauto?
There's some stealth for about 5 minutes but you end up shooting everyone in the face anyway.
After the game ends you unlock a challenge room" but I don't care.



---SPOILERS BELOW---
There is one boss fight
date: a robot gun thing. When you kill it
hoursPlayed: you cure your water-power poisoning
voteText: and then it fades to black

votesHelpful:
just "crazy cult wants to cull humans". you never meet up with your pal who helped you through the first 75% of the game over the radio.



I'm glad I played it. I'm also glad I got it on sale.
I want more in the world of the game but I know it won't happen."

reviewText:
Want to play with water?
If you are water person, this is a game for you.

There is really a lot of water in it.
Swimming.
Flooding corridors and rooms.
Swimming fast.
Walking in water.
Shooting is so - so.
Your operator's jokes are so bad they're good.
There is some cover mechanics.
Few kinds of ammo for your gun.
Hacking minigame which does not suck or frustrate much.

A lot of environmental damage sources, think barrels, electric panels you can blow up to electrocute people.
Level design and graphics are quite nice.
Production value is ok.
It's over in 5 hours, but a lot cheaper than a movie ticket.

I do recommend, but don't expect insane replayability value.
This is a linear game that will allow you to play with water :>
